assets.title: ProductCluster - 3rd-party, ClusterXL, Multi-Domain Security Management
assets.raw: ProductCluster - 3rd-party, ClusterXL, Multi-Domain Security Management, Quantum Security Gateways, Quantum Security Management VersionR80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82 OSGaia Last Modified2025-01-15 ## Solution Gaia has introduced an all-new Portal that provides full access to system configuration. **Gaia Portal (WebUI) architecture** Gaia Portal (WebUI) is powered by an Apache server running on the Security Gateway or Security Management server. The Apache server handles HTTPS requests of Gaia via a CGI interface, passing the requests to the TCL scripts. Besides this, the Apache manages the sessions using a proprietary Apache module that works in coordination with the Gaia DB and RBA roles. The Client side is based on Javascript and CSS files powered by ExtJs Javascript library. The Gaia Portal, as system portal, functions with and without multi-portal I/S. When there is no multi-portal, the HTTPS requests go directly to the Apache process listening for HTTPS connections. Troubleshooting needs to be conducted when you have problems accessing the Gaia Portal, for example: - User cannot access the Gaia Portal. - User cannot access specific pages of the Gaia Portal. - Log in to Gaia Portal succeeded, but then the Gaia Portal is stuck. - The browser displays errors on several pages. **Table of Contents** 1. Browser displays an error 2. Error on specific page in Gaia Portal 3. Gaia Portal fails to execute a command or function 4. Gaia Portal crashes 5. Gaia Portal failed to load 6. Access to Gaia Portal failed 7. Gaia Portal failed to load showing blank page 8. Changing the Gaia Portal port in Clish results in warning 9. Cannot accessÂ Gaia portal,Â browser shows "Page cannot be displayed" 10. Cannot connect to Gaia portal after changing the name of Security Gateway 11. Gaia Portal is not accessible/responsive after upgrade ### (1) Browser displays an error - Check with other supported browsers - Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome and Safari - refer to relevant _Gaia Administration Guide_ and to [sk92668 - Browsers supported to work with Gaia Portal](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk92668). - Open the browser console, and see if there is any error message: - in Google Chrome, press _**F12**_ and go to _**Console**_ tab - in FireFox, press CTRL+Shift+J keys - Related solution:Â [sk118801 - "ERR\_CONNECTION\_REFUSED" error is displayed in web browser when connecting to Gaia Portal](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk118801) ### (2) Error on specific page in Gaia Portal Click Here to Collapse instructions for all browsers ### (3) Gaia Portal fails to execute a command or function Check the same command in Gaia Clish: - If the command works correctly - Probably, this is a Gaia Portal problem. - Check browser logs. Refer to section "Browser displays an error". - Check TCL server side logs: - Using the browser console or Apache logs _/usr/local/apache2/logs_, find the name of the TCL file being accessed by the browser. - Every TCL file has its debug file. Edit the TCL file that is located in the _the /web/cgi-bin2/_ directory. - Look for the debug file name (should be something like _/tmp/.debug_). - Examine this log file. - Check _/var/log/messages_ file to see errors of _ipstcl_ process (the TCL interpreter). - If the command does not work - probably, this is Gaia Database problem. Check the _/var/log/messages_ file. ### (4) Gaia Portal crashes - Check browser logs with the browser console. - Check the relevant log files: - _/var/log/messages\*_ files - Apache logs in the _/usr/local/apache2/logs/_ directory ### (5) Gaia Portal failed to load The reasons for this issue can vary and may occur at different layers. Below are steps and instructions on how to narrow the troubleshooting scope. Show / Hide Solution - Check if you have connectivity to the machine from the client machine via ping. Capture the traffic with _**tcpdump**_ to see if pings can reach the machine. - When browsing to the Gaia portal, check the HTTPS connections: - Capture the traffic with _**tcpdump**_ to see that the HTTPS connections are being seen on the machine. - If HTTPS connections are seen on the machine, and this machine is Security Gateway / Cluster member, then run a simple kernel debug to check these HTTPS connections are dropped: _**fw ctl zdebug + drop**_. If there is a doubt, and this machine _**is NOT connected to any network**_ (except your test computer), then try unloading the Firewall policy: _**fw unloadlocal**_ (to reload the policy, run: _**fw fetch localhost**_ command). - Check if the Multi-Portal is not routing the Gaia connections to the wrong portal. Run _**fw ctl zdebug + crypt**_ command. If there is a doubt, and this machine _**is NOT connected to any network**_ (except your test computer), then try unloading the Firewall policy to disable Multi-Portal: _**fw unloadlocal**_ (to reload the policy, run: _**fw fetch localhost**_ command). - If indeed Multi-Portal routes the Gaia connections to the wrong portal, then check that the Gaia Portal port is configured inÂ SmartConsoleÂ in the corresponding object and see that the browser connects to the same port. - Check the Apache server logs to see if Gaia connections arrive at the Apache server: - Examine the files in the _**/usr/local/apache2/logs/**_ Â  - Examine the files _**/var/log/httpd2\_\***_ and _**/var/log/httpd\_\***_ - Check the ownership and permissions of the TCL files in the _/web/cgi-bin2/_ directory with _**ls -al /web/cgi-bin2/**_ command. These TCL files should have: - The following ownership: _**admin root**_ - The following permissions: _**\-r-xr-xr-x**_ Note: the _httpd\_dyno.tcl_ file located in this directory, has different permissions since it is obsolete and is not used by Gaia Portal anymore. To correct the ownership / permissions, run: - For ownership: _**chown -v admin:root /web/cgi-bin2/\***_ - For permissions: _**chmod -v a=rx /web/cgi-bin2/\***_ - Check the ownership and permissions of _/usr/bin/cgisu_ file with _ls -l /usr/bin/cgisu_ command. This file should have: - The following ownership: _**admin config**_ - The following permissions: _**\-r-sr-x---**_ To correct the ownership / permissions, run: - For ownership: _**chown -v admin:config /usr/bin/cgisu\***_ - For permissions: _**chmod -v 4550 /usr/bin/cgisu**_ - Check that the files _**/web/conf/server.key**_ and _**/web/conf/server.crt**_ are _not_ empty with the following commands: - _**cat /web/conf/server.key**_ - _**cat /web/conf/server.crt**_ Related solutions: - [sk97648: How to create and set certificate for Gaia Portal](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk97648) - [sk108252: How to change Gaia Portal's certificate from SHA-1 to SHA-256](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk108252) - [sk109593: How to configure Gaia Portal to use a 3rd party CA-issued Wildcard certificate](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk109593) ### (6) Access to Gaia Portal failed Check the ownership and permissions for _/tmp_ directory. This directory should have: - The following ownership: _**admin root**_ - The following permissions: _**drwxrwxrwt**_ To correct the ownership / permissions, run: - For ownership: _**chown -v admin:root /tmp**_ - For permissions: _**chmod -v a=rwxt /tmp**_ ### (7) Gaia Portal failed to load showing only blank page Enable JavaScript in your browser. For more information, refer to [http://www.enable-javascript.com](http://www.enable-javascript.com/). ### (8) Changing the Gaia Portal port in Clish results in warning > "_WARNING This command is for initial use. SSL port should be set through SmartDashboard. Changing the port may cause inconsistency with the settings on the SmartDashboard. Are you sure you want to continue?(Y/N)_ > _\[N\]_ > _"It is recommended to change the port using the Platform Portal section of the object in SmartDashboard._ > _Add the port to the end of the Main URL and push policy._ _"show web ssl-port" should now display the port in the Main URL_ Show / Hide Solution **For Security Gateway**: In SmartConsole, perform: 1. Open the Security Gateway / Cluster object and go to the "Platform Portal" pane. 2. In the "Main URL" field, set the desired port (e.g., port 4434): _https://IP\_ADDRESS:PORT_ 3. Click on OK to apply the changes. 4. Install the security policy on this Security Gateway / Cluster object. **Note**: Using Clish to change portal port on Security Gateway will be overwritten on a policy installation. After the change the httpd process can be seen listening to the new port with "_netstat -lpn|grep port_". Port 443 is handled by he mpdaemon and will not be listed in netstat. **For Security Management Server**: 1. Connect to command line on Security Management Server and log in to Clish. 2. Set the desired port (e.g., port 4434): _HostName> set web ssl-port _ 3. Save the changes:Â _HostName> save config_ 4. Verify that the configuration was saved: _\[Expert@HostName\]# grep 'httpd:ssl\_port' /config/db/initial_ ### (9)Â Cannot access Gaia portal,Â browser shows "Page cannot be displayed" - When accessing Gaia portal, it loads for 1-2 seconds and then the browser displays the "_This page cannot be displayed_" message. - WebUI debug output according to [sk84561](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk84561) contains: \[error\] (17)File exists: Cannot create SSLMutex with file \`/usr/local/apache2/logs/ssl\_mutex' Configuration Failed Show / Hide SolutionÂ  To resolve the problem, remove the _ssl\_mutex_ file: 1. RunÂ _\# rm -r /usr/local/apache2/logs/ssl\_mutex_ 2. Restart the web server daemon: _\# tellpm process:httpd2 __\# tellpm process:httpd2 t_ ### (10) Cannot connect to Gaia portal after changing the name of Security Gateway After the name of the Security Gateway is changed and SIC is reset with the Management server, there is a certificate error and Gaia portal page does not load. Cause: Old certificate was not removed from the Security Gateway before changing its name. Show / Hide SolutionÂ  1. In SmartConsole, go to the 'Security Gateway object -> IPSec VPN -> Repository Of Certificates Available to the Gateway', and delete the certificate that contains the old name of the gateway. 2. If the firewall does not have the IPSEC VPN blade enabled, temporarily enable this blade under General Properties and view the Certificate(s) available to the gateway. **Exercise caution to ensure that the certificate is issued by the Security Management server**, as in the example below: _Subject: CN=GwyC-77.10 VPN Certificate,O=Mgmt..imce48 __Issuer: O=Mgmt..imce48_ 3. Ensure that the issuer name shows the Security Management server name. 4. After successfully confirming step 3 above, click "OK" and highlight the certificate again and click "Remove". 5. A warning will come up that the certificate will be removed and a new one will be generated--click "OK" or "yes". 6. Go back and confirm that the new certificate now shows the new hostname. 7. Install policy to the Security Gateway in question, and now there should be access to the WebUI. ### (11) Gaia Portal is not accessible/responsive after upgrade Symptoms: - Gaia Portal is stuck in the loading icon after entering username and password. - "`The URL you requested could not be found on the server`" message is displayed in the Web browser. - "`sec_error_reused_issuer_and_serial`" message is displayed in the Web browser. - Debug of Gaia Portal per [sk84561](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk84561) - `/var/log/httpd2_error_log` file - repeatedly shows: `Error: unable to stat file /tmp/.xsl: No such file or directory, referer: https:///.../cgi-bin/home.tcl` - `"No WebUI and RBA error - permission denied"` is repeated in `/var/log/messages` Possible reasons:Â  - CPWMD process fails to start. - Wrong permissions were set to the WebUI web server files/directories. - Wrong permissions were set to the /tmp directory. Show / Hide this Section **Note:** Close the web browser before making any modifications. Web browsers can cache a negative connection attempt. Permissions of the `/tmp` directory should be as follows: > ``` > drwxrwxrwt 5 admin root 4096 Jan 2 11:21 /tmp > ``` **Notes**: - To view the current permissions of a _directory_, use the '[`ls -ld`](http://linux.die.net/man/1/ls)' command on the directory: `[Expert@HostName]# ls -ld /tmp` - To change the _access_ permissions, use the '[`chmod`](http://linux.die.net/man/1/chmod)' command: `[Expert@HostName]# chmod [-R] u=[rwx],g=[rwx],o=[rwx] TARGET_DIRECTORY` where - '`-R`' flag should be used for recursive change (for all files inside a directory). - '`u=[rwx],g=[rwx],o=[rwx]`' should be used for setting the specific permission for User, Group, Others. To set the default permissions for the `/tmp` directory, run: **`[Expert@HostName]# chmod a=rwxt /tmp`** Run '`chmod --help`' for more information. - To change the _ownership_ permissions, use the '[`chown`](http://linux.die.net/man/1/chown)' command: `[Expert@HostName]# chown [-R] USER:GROUP TARGET_DIRECTORY` where - '`-R`' flag should be used for recursive change (for all files inside a directory). Run '`chown --help`' for more information. ## Article Properties OriginatorGhanim Fodi Technical ResourceTal Martsiano Access LevelGeneral StatusApproved Date Created2013-01-16 Last Modified2025-01-15 EditorGil Frantsus Last ApproverStella Shteinbuk ## Comments #### Internal only SK is relevant also to R82.10 This article is merged with sk83482, sk96117, sk89100 and sk65319 **Important note:Â Prior to using the tools mentioned in this article, make sure you thoroughly go overÂ [sk156153 - Best Practice Guide for Debugging Check Point Products](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk156153).** **This SK is managed by the SecureKnowledge Team. Do not edit it yourself. If you need to make changes/updates to it, submit the feedback (using the field at the bottom of this SK), or contact the SK owner (shown in the top header).** ___ **Troubleshooting** Iit has been found that disabling UserCheck resolved issue accessing the WebUI (SR 1-8696853551, 5-1270222041) The following procedure: 1. Open SmartDashboard 2. Edit the Cluster object, go to User Check 3. Clear the "Enable UserCheck for active blades" checkbox 4. Install policy

assets.title: ProductClusterXL - Global Kernel Parameters for Cluster Members
assets.raw:
ProductClusterXL VersionR80.30SP (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82 OSGaia Last Modified2024-12-08 ## Symptoms - Cluster members repeatedly fail-over during high CPU utilization. - Cluster members fail-over during policy installation. ## Solution **Table of Contents:** - Introduction - Troubleshooting guidelines - Definitions - Background - Checklist - Legend - List of Kernel Parameters - Cluster flapping during policy installation - Cluster flapping during run time - Notes ## Introduction The article contains a list of various relevant global kernel parameters that can be configured on cluster members in ClusterXL configured in High Availability mode to prevent cluster flapping: - `fwha_cul_cluster_log_delay_millisec` - `fwha_cul_cluster_short_timeout` - `fwha_cul_mechanism_enable` - `fwha_cul_member_cpu_load_limit` - `fwha_cul_member_long_timeout` - `fwha_cul_policy_freeze_event_timeout_millisec` - `fwha_cul_policy_freeze_timeout_millisec` - `fwha_dead_timeout_multiplier` - `fwha_freeze_state_machine_timeout` - `fwha_if_connectivity_tolerance` - `fwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_cpu_load_limit` - `fwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_disable_feature_timeout` - `fwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_monitor_cpu` - `fwha_policy_update_timeout_factor` **Important Notes:** - This article applies only to ClusterXL configured in High Availability mode. - Cluster Under Load (CUL) mechanism is _**not**_ needed in OPSEC / 3rd party clusters because in such clusters, Check Point cluster does not make any decision regarding the states of cluster members. ## Troubleshooting guidelines Note: For additional information, refer to Related solutions section. ### Definitions Flapping - Consequent changes in the state of either cluster interfaces (cluster interface flapping), or cluster members (cluster member flapping). Such consequent changes in the state are seen in SmartConsole > Logs (if in in a cluster object, the cluster administrator set '`Track changes in the status of cluster members`' to '`Log`'). ClusterXL relies completely on the Cluster Control Protocol (CCP) - proprietary Check Point protocol that runs between cluster members on UDP port 8116, and has the following roles: - State Synchronization (Delta Sync) - Health checks (state of cluster members and of cluster interfaces): - Health-status Reports - Cluster-member Probing - State-change Commands - Querying for Cluster Membership ### Background If the Cluster Control Protocol (CCP) packets are not sent/received within the predefined timeouts, the state of an interface and/or of a cluster member might change to 'Down' (i.e., failed). This, in turn, might cause fail-over between cluster members. Depending on the root causes of these issues with sending and receiving of CCP packets, the state of an interface and/or of a member might change occasionally, or repeatedly (flap). The following are most common reasons for issues with sending and receiving of CCP packets: - high CPU load on cluster member(s) - overloaded interface(s) on cluster member(s) - latency on the network - congestion on the network ### Checklist 1. Determine the nature of the issue - does the state of an interface change, or the state of a member change (or both). Note: Check the cluster-related messages in SmartView Tracker. 2. Determine the frequency on the issue - does the state of an interface and/or of a member change occasionally, or repeatedly (flap). Note: Analyze the cluster-related messages in SmartView Tracker. 3. Check whether there is an apparent trigger for this issue (e.g., only policy installation, only during specific hours, etc.). Note: Correlate the cluster-related messages in SmartView Tracker to traffic logs and to messages in 'Management' log (Audit log). 4. Check the CPU load on all cluster members during the issue. Note: Correlate outputs of these commands: '`top`', '`ps auxwf`', and '`vmstat 1`' (commands should be run simultaneously each second - best practice is to create a shell script that runs these commands in a loop). Refer to [sk98348: Best Practices - Security Gateway Performance](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk98348)Â /Â [sk33781: Performance analysis for Security Gateway NGX R65 / R7x](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk33781). 5. Check the load on the problematic interfaces on all cluster members during the issue. Note: Correlate the cluster-related messages in SmartView Tracker to output of '`netstat -ni`' command. 6. Run and analyze the cluster debug on all cluster members during the issue. Note: [Contact Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html) to get the debug instructions relevant to your specific case. It is recommended to collect the CPU load during this debug (collect outputs of '`top`', '`ps`', '`vmstat`' commands). 7. When the trigger for cluster flapping is identified, use the relevant kernel parameters listed below to fine tune the cluster (refer to Notes section for instructions on how to set the desired values for kernel parameters). ## Legend Each global kernel parameter is described in _the form of a table_:
Relevant global kernel parameterThis cell contains the exact name of global kernel parameter.
DescriptionThis cell contains a short description of this global kernel parameter.
Default valueThis cell contains the default value of this global kernel parameter.
Recommended valueThis cell contains the recommended value that should be set for this global kernel parameter if your cluster flaps in the described scenario.
ImpactThis cell contains possible impact of changing the value of this global kernel parameter from default value to other value.
Supported versionsThis cell contains the list of versions that support this global kernel parameter.
Note: If specific parameter is not integrated in your version, then contact Check Point Support to get a Hotfix that will add that parameter to you Security Gateway.
CommentThis cell contains additional related information.
## List of Kernel Parameters **Important Note:** Some internal cluster timers use special time units - `HTU ("HA Time Unit")`, where `1 HTU = 100 milliseconds = 0.1 second`. All the relevant kernel parameters were divided into two major groups: - Cluster flapping during policy installation - Cluster flapping during run time Let us review the relevant kernel parameters: - #### Cluster flapping during policy installation Causes: - FWD pnote and/or CPHAD pnote reports its state as '`problem`' due to failure of the `fwd` daemon and/or the `cphamcset` daemon to send periodic report to Check Point kernel. - Standby member becomes Active, while the original Active member is functioning and considered up, as it does not receive CCP packets from the original Active member. - Standby member becomes Active, while the original Active member is functioning and considered up, as it completes the policy installation before the original Active member. Relevant kernel parameters:
Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_freeze_state_machine_timeout
Description
  • Freeze member's state for N seconds, starting from cluster policy installation time.
  • If a Standby member does not receive CCP packets from the Active member (e.g., the Active member is overloaded or crashes), it will change its state to Active.
Default value40 sec - from R80.10 and higher
Recommended value200 seconds
ImpactNone
Supported versionsAll
CommentRefer to sk32488.
Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_policy_update_timeout_factor
DescriptionMultiplier for a policy state synchronization timeout between cluster members - after this timeout, a cluster member gives up and does not wait anymore for policy/configuration update:
[20 seconds x (number of members in cluster) x fwha_policy_update_timeout_factor]
Default value
Default
Value		Cluster
Versions

  • R80.20SP and R80.30SP for Scalable Platforms

Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_monitor_cpu
DescriptionAvoid pnote failure during CPU load for default of 180 sec.
Notes:
  • configurable
  • each member monitors its local load
  • system load is not advertised between members
Default value0 (feature is disabled)
Recommended value1 (feature is enabled)
Impact
  • During high CPU load, failover might not occur due to FWD and/or CPHAD pnotes.
  • No logs / alert during the timeout period, until FWD daemon recovers.

Note: This parameter is not relevant in the versions R77.30 and higher.
Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_cpu_load_limit
DescriptionAverage CPU utilization threshold in per cent for the member to consider itself under load.

Note: This parameter is not relevant in the versions R77.30 and higher.
Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_pnote_timeout_mechanism_disable_feature_timeout
DescriptionAvoid failover when a pnote reports its status as 'problem' for the duration of VALUE HTUs (1 "HA Time Unit" = 100 milliseconds).
Default value1800 HTUs (= 180 sec)
Recommended value1800 HTUs (= 180 sec)
ImpactNone
Supported versionsR71 - R77.20

Note: This parameter is not relevant in the versions R77.30 and higher.
Relevant global kernel parameterfwha_cul_mechanism_enable
DescriptionEnables Cluster Under Load (CUL) mechanism - avoid failure due to pnote reporting its status as 'problem' and freeze the state of cluster member during CPU load time.
Note: each member monitors its local load and advertises it among other members.
Default value1 - from R77 and higher
Recommended value1 (feature is enabled)
Impact
  • In case Active member fails, network outage for VALUE of 'fwha_cul_cluster_short_timeout'.
  • Starting in R76, pnotes related to User Space processes are not monitored (sk92878).
  • Enabling this feature does not affect pnotes.
Supported versionsStarting in R75.40VS (not including R75.45, R75.46)

Kernel debug Click Here to Collapse the Entire Article ### (1) The Need for Suspicious Activity Rules The fast-changing environment of network security requires that you be able to react immediately to a security problem without having to change the entire network's Firewall rule base (for example, when you want to block a specific user). To achieve this you must make sure that all inbound and outbound network activity is inspected and identified as suspicious when necessary (for example, when network or system activity indicates that someone is attempting to break in). ### (2) Suspicious Activity Rules Solution The Suspicious Activity Monitoring (SAM) utility is integrated into SmartView Monitor. The utility blocks activities that you see in the SmartView Monitor's results and that appear to be suspicious. Using SAM, you can block a user who tries several times to gain unauthorized access to a network or Internet resource. The firewall rules in a SAM-enabled Security Gateway block suspicious connections that are not restricted by the security policy. These rules are applied immediately (Install Policy is not required). ### (3) Creating a New Suspicious Activity Rule **Note:** SAM rules consume some CPU resources on a Security Gateway. Accordingly, set an expiration that gives you time to investigate but does not affect performance. The best practice is to keep only the SAM rules that you need. If you confirm that an activity is risky, edit the Security Policy, educate users, or otherwise handle the risk. Configure the relevant settings in the Suspicious Activity rule. _Example_: [![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk112061/R7x_Right_Click_Block_Service_Block_Suspicious_Activity_rule.png)](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk112061/R7x_Right_Click_Block_Service_Block_Suspicious_Activity_rule.png "Click the image to see it in full size in a new tab/window") 6. Click on _**Enforce**_ button. **Important Note:** It is not possible to edit the SAM rule after clicking on this button. The current rule would have to be deleted and a new rule would have to be configured. ### (5) Managing Suspicious Activity Rules Show / Hide this section 1. Open SmartView Monitor GUI: - Instructions for R8x versions: 1. Connect with SmartConsole to Security Management Server / Domain Management Server. 2. In the _Application main navigation pane_, click on _**LOGS & MONITOR**_. 3. At the top, go to _**New Tab**_ tab. 4. At the bottom, in the _**External Apps**_ section, click on _**Tunnel & User Monitoring**_: [![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk112061/R8x_Tunnel_and_User_Monitoring.png)](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk112061/R8x_Tunnel_and_User_Monitoring.png "Click the image to see it in full size in a new tab/window") 5. SmartView Monitor GUI opens. - Instructions for R7x versions: 1. Connect with SmartView Monitor to Security Management Server / Domain Management Server. 2. Go to _**Suspicious Activity Rules...**_: - Either click on the _**Suspicious Activity Rules**_ button on the toolbar: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk112061/Suspicious_Activity_Rules_button.png) - Or go to the _main menu_ - go to _**View**_ menu - click on _**Menu Bar**_, and then, go to _**Tools**_ menu - click on the _**Suspicious Activity Rules...**_: 3. The _**Enforced Suspicious Activity Rules**_ window opens. - To see the configured rules on all managed Security Gateways, select _**Apply on All**_ option - To see the configured rules on a specific Security Gateway, select _**Show On**_ option and select the relevant Security Gateway object. 4. You can remove a specific SAM rule, or all SAM rules at once. Note: If you added a SAM rule that conflicts with another SAM rule, then the _conflicting_ SAM rule remains hidden. For example, if you define a SAM rule to drop _http_ traffic, and a SAM rule already exists to reject _http_ traffic, then only the "drop" SAM rule will be shown. If you delete the "drop" SAM rule, then the "reject" SAM rule will appear. ### (6) Working with SAM Server from CLI (fw sam) The _**fw sam**_ command can be used to work with Suspicious Activity Rules from the CLI on either Security Management Server / Domain Management Server, or Security Gateway. **Note:** **The "`fw sam`" command is not supported on Quantum Maestro and Scalable Chassis.** Show / Hide this section - To Add/Cancel SAM rule according to criteria: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam \[-v\] \[-s \] \[-S \] \[-f \] \[-t \] \[-l \] \[-C\] \[-e \]+ \[-r\] -{n|i|I|j|J} **_ - To delete all SAM rules: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam \[-v\] \[-s \] \[-S \] \[-f \] -D**_ - To monitor all SAM rules: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam \[-v\] \[-s \] \[-S \] \[-f \] \[-r\] -M -{i|j|n|b|q} all**_ - To monitor SAM rules according to criteria: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam \[-v\] \[-s \] \[-S \] \[-f \] \[-r\] -M -{i|j|n|b|q} **_ where: >
ParameterDescription
-dEnables debug mode for fw command. Writes to local stderr.
-vEnables verbose mode. Writes one message (describing whether the command was successful or not) to stderr for each Security Gateway machine, on which the command is enforced.
-s <SAM_Server>Specifies IP address (in the X.X.X.X format) / resolvable HostName of Security Gateway that will enforce the command.
The default is localhost.
-S <SIC_Name_of_SAM_Server>The SIC name for the SAM server to be contacted. It is expected that the SAM server will have this SIC name, otherwise the connection will fail.
If no server SIC name is supplied, the connection will proceed without SIC names comparison.
For more information about enabling SIC, refer to the OPSEC API Specification.
On VSX Gateway, run the fw vsx showncs -vs <VSID> command to show the SIC name for the relevant Virtual System. 
-f <Security_Gateway>

Specifies the Security Gateway machine on which to enforce the action:

  • All - Default. Specifies that the action should be enforced on all managed Security Gateways where SAM Server runs.
    This syntax can be used only on Security Management Server / Domain Management Server.

  • localhost - Specifies that the action should be enforced on this local machine (on which the "fw sam" command is being executed).
    This syntax can be used only on Security Gateway / StandAlone.

  • Gateways - Specifies that the action should be enforced on all objects defined as Security Gateways, on which SAM Server runs.
    This syntax can be used only on Security Management Server / Domain Management Server.

  • Name of Security Gateway object - Specifies that the action should be enforced on this specific Security Gateway object.
    This syntax should be used only on Security Management Server / Domain Management Server.

  • Name of Group object - Specifies that the action should be enforced on all specific Security Gateways in this Group object.
    This syntax can be used only on Security Management Server / Domain Management Server.

-D

Cancels all inhibit (-i, -j,-I,-J) and notify (-n) commands.

To "uninhibit" the inhibited connections, execute "fw sam" command with the "-C" or "-D" parameters.
It is also possible to use this command for active SAM requests.
-CCancels the "fw sam" command to inhibit connections with the specified parameters.
These connections will no longer be inhibited (rejected or dropped).
The command parameters must match the ones in the original "fw sam" command, except for the "-t <Timeout>" parameter.
-t <Timeout>Specifies the time period (in seconds) during which the action will be enforced.
The default is forever, or until cancelled.
-l <Log_Type>

Specifies the type of the log for enforced action:

  • nolog - Does not generates any Log / Alert
  • short_noalert - Generates a Log
  • short_alert - Generates an Alert
  • long_noalert - Generates a Log
  • long_alert - Generates an Alert (default)
-e <key=val>+

Specifies rule information based on the keys and the provided values.
Multiple keys are separated by the plus sign (+).
Available keys are:

  • name - security rule name (limited to 100 characters)
  • comment - security rule comment (limited to 100 characters)
  • originator - security rule originator's username (limited to 100 characters)
-rSpecifies that all IP addresses should be resolved.
-nSpecifies that a "Notify" long-format log entry should be generated.
Generates an alert when connections that match the specified services or IP addresses pass through the FireWall.
This action does not inhibit / close connections.
-iInhibits (do not allow) new connections with the specified parameters.
Each inhibited connection is logged according to log type.
Matching connections will be rejected.
-IInhibits new connections with the specified parameters, and closes all existing connections with the specified parameters.
Each inhibited connection is logged according to the log type.
Matching connections will be rejected.
-jInhibits new connections with the specified parameters.
Each inhibited connection is logged according to the log type.
Matching connections will be dropped.
-JInhibits new connections with the specified parameters, and closes all existing connections with the specified parameters.
Each inhibited connection is logged according to the log type.
Matching connections will be dropped.
-bBypasses new connections with the specified parameters.
-qQuarantines new connections with the specified parameters.
-MMonitors the active SAM requests with the specified actions and criteria.
allGets all active SAM requests.
Used for monitoring purposes only.
<Criteria>

Criteria are used to match connections, and are composed of various combinations of the following parameters:

  • Source IP Address
  • Source Netmask
  • Destination IP Address
  • Destination Netmask
  • Service (per IANA Service Name and Port Number Registry)
  • Protocol Number (per IANA Protocol Numbers)

Possible combinations are:

  • src <ip>
  • dst <ip>
  • any <<ip>
  • subsrc <ip> <netmask>
  • subdst <ip> <netmask>
  • subany <ip> <netmask>
  • srv <src ip> <dest ip> <service> <protocol>
  • subsrv <src ip> <src netmask> <dest ip> <dest netmask> <service> <protocol>
  • subsrvs <src ip> <src netmask> <dest ip> <service> <protocol>
  • subsrvd <src ip> <dest ip> <dest netmask> <service> <protocol>
  • dstsrv <dest ip> <service> <protocol>
  • subdstsrv <dest ip> <dest netmask> <service> <protocol>
  • srcpr <ip> <protocol>
  • dstpr <ip> <protocol>
  • subsrcpr <ip> <netmask> <protocol>
  • subdstpr <ip> <netmask> <protocol>
  • generic <key=val>

where:

ParameterDescription
src <ip>Matches the Source IP address of the connection.
dst <ip>Matches the Destination IP address of the connection.
any <ip>Matches either the Source IP address or the Destination IP address of the connection.
subsrc <ip> <netmask>Matches the Source IP address of the connections according to the netmask.
subdst <ip> <netmask>Matches the Destination IP address of the connections according to the netmask.
subany <ip> <netmask>Matches either the Source IP address or Destination IP address of connections according to the netmask.
srv <src ip> <dest ip> <service> <protocol>Matches the specific Source IP address, Destination IP address, Service (port number) and Protocol.
subsrv <src ip> <netmask> <dest ip> <netmask> <service> <protocol>Matches the specific Source IP address, Destination IP address, Service (port number) and Protocol.
Source and Destination IP addresses are assigned according to the netmask.
subsrvs <src ip> <src netmask> <dest ip> <service> <protocol>Matches the specific Source IP address, source netmask, destination netmask, Service (port number) and Protocol.
subsrvd <src ip> <dest ip> <dest netmask> <service> <protocol>Matches specific Source IP address, Destination IP, destination netmask, Service (port number) and Protocol.
dstsrv <dest ip> <service> <protocol>Matches specific Destination IP address, Service (port number) and Protocol.
subdstsrv <dest ip> <netmask> <service> <protocol>Matches specific Destination IP address, Service (port number) and Protocol.
Destination IP address is assigned according to the netmask.
srcpr <ip> <protocol>Matches the Source IP address and protocol.
dstpr <ip> <protocol>Matches the Destination IP address and protocol.
subsrcpr <ip> <netmask> <protocol>Matches the Source IP address and protocol of connections.
Source IP address is assigned according to the netmask.
subdstpr <ip> <netmask> <protocol>Matches the Destination IP address and protocol of connections.
Destination IP address is assigned according to the netmask.
generic <key=val>+

Matches the GTP connections based on the specified keys and provided values.
Multiple keys are separated by the plus sign (+).
Available keys are:

  • service=gtp
  • imsi
  • msisdn
  • apn
  • tunl_dst
  • tunl_dport
  • tunl_proto
**Notes:** - Logs for enforced SAM rules (configured with _fw sam_ command) are stored in the _**$FWDIR/log/sam.dat**_ file. By design, the file is purged automatically after you enable the **Purge SAM file when it reaches: option:** in the Security Gateway / Cluster Object **Properties** \> **Other** \> **SAM**. This data log file contains the records in one of the following formats: - ,,, - ,,,,,, - SAM Requests are stored in the kernel table _**sam\_requests**_ on the Security Gateway. - IP Addresses blocked by SAM rules are stored in the kernel table _**sam\_blocked\_ips**_ on the Security Gateway. ### (7) Working with SAM Policy editor from CLI (fw sam\_policy) The _**fw sam\_policy**_ command can be used to work with the Suspicious Activity Policy editor from the CLI on either Security Management Server / Domain Management Server, or Security Gateway. Show / Hide this section - To add a new SAM policy rule: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw sam\_policy add \[-u\] \[-f \] \[-t \] {\[-a \]} \[-l \] \[-n \] \[-c \] \[-o \] ip **_ where: >
ParameterDescription
-dEnables debug mode for fw command. Writes to local stderr.
-uSpecifies that this is a user-defined rule.
-f <Security_Gateway>

Specifies the Security Gateway machine on which to enforce the policy:

  • all - Default. Specifies that the policy should be enforced on all managed Security Gateways.

  • Name of Security Gateway object - Specifies that the policy should be enforced on this specific Security Gateway object.

  • Name of Group object - Specifies that the policy should be enforced on all specific Security Gateways in this Group object.

-t <Timeout>Specifies the time period (in seconds) during which the policy will be enforced.
-a <d | r | n | q | i>

Specifies the action:

  • d - Drop the connection
  • r - Reject the connection
  • n - Notify the connection
  • q - Quarantine the connection
  • i - Inspect the connection
-t <Timeout>Specifies the time period (in seconds) during which the policy will be enforced.
-l <r | a>

Specifies the log type:

  • r - Regular log
  • a - Alert
-n <name>Specifies the security rule name.
-c <comment>Specifies the security rule comment.
-o <originator>Specifies the security rule originator.
-z <zone>Specifies the security zone.
ip <IP filter arguments>

Specifies that rule should be added with IP filter arguments:

[-C] [-s <src ip>] [-m <src mask>] [-d <dst ip>] [-M <dst mask>] [-p <port>] [-r <proto>]

where:

ParameterDescription
-CSpecifies that open connections should be closed.
-s <src ip>Specifies Source IP address.
-m <src mask>Specifies Source subnet mask (in dotted decimal format).
-d <dst ip>Specifies Destination IP address.
-M <dst mask>Specifies Destination subnet mask (in dotted decimal format).
-p <port>Specifies port number (per IANA Service Name and Port Number Registry).
-r <proto>Specifies protocol number (per IANA Protocol Numbers).
- To delete an existing SAM policy rule: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam\_policy del ""**_ where: >
ParameterDescription
-dEnables debug mode for fw command. Writes to local stderr.
"<uid>"Unique identifier of an existing SAM rule, as obtained from the output of fw sam_policy get command.
Example:
fw sam_policy del "<5779378c,00000000,64291eac,00005584>"
- To get the SAM policy: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam\_policy get \[-l\] \[-u \] \[-k -t \[+{-v }\] \[-n\]\]**_ where: >
ParameterDescription
-dEnables debug mode for fw command. Writes to local stderr.
-lPrints rule's parameters of each rule on separate lines
(instead of printing each entire rule on a separate line).
-u <uid>Specifies rule UID (can be combined with a filter).
-k <key>Specifies the key of predicate.
-t <in>Specifies the type of predicate.
-v <val>Specifies the value of predicate.
-nNegation.
Example output: > `[Expert@HostName:0]# fw sam_policy get Get operation succeeded operation=add uid=<5779372c,00000000,64291eac,00005530> target=all timeout=5622 action=notify log=log close= src_ip_addr=172.30.254.254 req_type=ip operation=add uid=<5779378c,00000000,64291eac,00005584> target=all timeout=5884 action=notify log=log close= src_ip_addr=172.30.244.244 req_type=ip` - To read add/del SAM policy rules from standard input: _**\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw \[-d\] sam\_policy batch \[-F \]**_ where: >
ParameterDescription
-dEnables debug mode for fw command. Writes to local stderr.
-F <separator>Specifies the separator between command arguments.
**Notes:** - SAM Policy rules (configured with _fw sam\_policy_ command) are stored in the _**$FWDIR/database/sam\_policy.db**_ file. - SAM Policy management file is _**$FWDIR/database/sam\_policy.mng**_. ### (8) Kernel debug Show / Hide this section The following kernel debug on the Security Gateway shows information about the enforcement of SAM rules (that were configured either in SmartView Monitor, or with _fw sam_ command): 1. Prepare: _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl debug 0_ _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl debug -buf 32000_ _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl debug -m fw + sam conn drop_ 2. Verify: _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl debug -m fw_ 3. Start: _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl kdebug -T -f > /var/log/debug\_sam.txt_ 4. Replicate the issue. 5. Stop: Press CTRL+C, and run _\[Expert@HostName:0\]# fw ctl debug 0_ 6. Analyze: _/var/log/debug\_sam.txt_ ## Article Properties OriginatorInocente Sandoval Technical ResourceRobert Ruiz Access LevelAdvanced StatusApproved Date Created2016-06-27 Last Modified2025-04-03 EditorLiron Rubin Last ApproverSergei Shir ## Comments #### Internal only - Per Eric Dale's request, all references to the "quota" keyword were removed from this SK.Â  - Per Tal Ben Avraham, the "fw sam" command will not be supported on Quantum Maestro and Scalable Chassis (02641733). "fwaccel dos" command should be used instead.

assets.title: CPView API Service Commands
assets.raw:
cpview

cpview --help

cpview --api_service {on | off | stat}

cpview --metric [--request_source <Source>] [--request_name <Name>] [--filter <Filter>]

cpview --print [--ignoreWarnings] [--showDesc] [--request_source <Source>] [--request_name <Name>] [--filter <Filter>]

cpview --services {on | off | stat | export}

cpview --history [<Timestamp>]

CommandDescription

cpview

Opens the interactive tool interface.

cpview -h

cpview --help

Shows the built-in help and exits.

cpview -a {on | off | stat}

cpview --api_service {on | off | stat}

Administration of the CPView API service (to query the data with API):

  • on - Enables the CPView API service (this is the default)

  • off - Disables the CPView API service

  • stat - Shows the status of the CPView API service

Example Output:

[Expert@R82:0]# cpview --api_service stat
CPView api service running
[Expert@R82:0]#

For information about the CPView API commands, see Gaia API Reference v1.8 (or higher) > Chapter "Diagnostics" > Section "CPView".

cpview -m [-e <Source>] [-r <Name>] [-f <Filter>]

cpview --metric [--request_source <Source>] [--request_name <Name>] [--filter <Filter>]

Raw print mode (JSON).

Shows all CPView metrics one time, in the Metric format for Skyline Telemetry (sk178566).

  • cpview -m

    cpview --metric

    Shows all CPView metrics, in the Metric format for Skyline Telemetry.

  • cpview -m -e <Source>

    cpview --metric --request_source <Source>

    Shows CPView metrics only the specified sources, in the Metric format for Skyline Telemetry.

  • cpview -m -r <Name>

    cpview --metric --request_name <Name>

    For internal Check Point use only.

    Shows CPView metrics only from the specified data producer, in the Metric format for Skyline Telemetry.

    In the $CPDIR/conf/cpview_api_service_conf.xml file, refer to the values in the parameter "requests_name". Example values: TP_ONLY, SDWAN_ONLY, SDWAN_AND_TP.

  • cpview -m -f <Filter>

    cpview --metric --filter <Filter>

    Shows only the specified CPView metrics, in the Metric format for Skyline Telemetry.

    You must specify the filter string that matches one of these - Metric ID, Statistics ID, or Internal Metric Label.

    To specify several filter strings, separate them with commas without spaces (a maximum of 512 characters). You must enclose the filter strings in quotes - each filter string ("String1","String2",...,"StringN") or all filter strings together ("String1,String2,...,StringN").
    Example: -f "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.num_of_cores","UM_STAT.UM_CPU.ds_status"

    • Metric ID

      Refer to one of these:

      • The "metric-id" value in the output of the "cpview -m" / "cpview --metric" command.

      • The Skyline Administration Guide > Chapter "Skyline Metrics Repository" > column "Metric ID".

      Important - In front of the filter string that matches a Metric ID, you must add the prefix "M:".

      Example Output - Formatted as pretty JSON:

      [Expert@R82:0]# cpview -m -f M:"system.cpu.count" | jq '.'
{
  "metrics": [
    {
      "data": [
        {
          "value": 4
        }
      ],
      "description": "The number of CPU cores on this machine.",
      "metric-id": "system.cpu.count",
      "metric-type": "Gauge",
      "metric-unit": "{cpu}",
      "metric-value-type": "double"
    }
  ],
  "timestamp": 1730744843
}

    • Statistics ID

      Refer to the "stat-id" value in the output of the "cpview -p" / "cpview --print" command.

      Example Output - Formatted as pretty JSON:

      [Expert@R82:0]# cpview -m -f "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.num_of_cores" | jq '.'
{
  "metrics": [
    {
      "data": [
        {
          "value": 4
        }
      ],
      "description": "The number of CPU cores on this machine.",
      "metric-id": "system.cpu.count",
      "metric-type": "Gauge",
      "metric-unit": "{cpu}",
      "metric-value-type": "double"
    }
  ],
  "timestamp": 1730737683
}

    • Internal Metric Label

      In the $CPDIR/conf/cpview_api_service_conf.xml file, refer to the values of the "labels=" parameters.

      Examples of Internal Metric Labels:

      • labels="CPU,Dynamic_Split,OS,Configuration"

      • labels="Hardware,Interfaces,Drops,Errors"

      In the CLI syntax, you can use any of these labels - one or several:

      • -f "CPU"
      • -f "Dynamic_Split"
      • -f "CPU,Dynamic_Split"
      • -f "Drops,Errors"
      • and so on

      Example Output - Formatted as pretty JSON:

      [Expert@R82:0]# cpview -m -f "Dynamic_Split" | jq '.'
{
  "metrics": [
    {
      "data": [
        {
          "value": 0
        }
      ],
      "description": "The state of the CoreXL Dynamic Balancing (On/Off).",
      "metric-id": "system.cpu.dynamic_balancing.state",
      "metric-type": "Gauge",
      "metric-unit": "{state}",
      "metric-value-type": "double"
    }
  ],
  "timestamp": 1730737802
}
[Expert@R82:0]#

cpview -p [-i] [-d] [-f <Filter>]

cpview --print [--ignoreWarnings] [--showDesc] [--filter <Filter>]

Simple print mode (JSON).

Shows all CPView metrics one time.

  • cpview -p

    cpview --print

    Shows all CPView metrics.

  • cpview -p -e <Source>

    cpview --print --request_source <Source>

    For internal Check Point use only.

    Specifies the source/entity of the data request that is sent to Check Point Cloud.

  • cpview -p -r <Name>

    cpview --print --request_name <Name>

    Shows only the specified CPView requests.

  • cpview -p -i

    cpview --print --ignoreWarnings

    Reserved for future use.

    Ignores warnings and continues to execute.

  • cpview -p -d

    cpview --print --showDesc

    Shows the additional "name" and "description" strings for each metric.

  • cpview -p -f <Filter>

    cpview --print --filter <Filter>

    Shows only the specified CPView metrics, together with the description, name, and type of each metric.

    You must specify the filter string that matches one of these - Statistics ID or Internal Metric Label.

    To specify several filter strings, separate them with commas without spaces (a maximum of 512 characters). You must enclose the filter strings in quotes - each filter string ("String1","String2",...,"StringN") or all filter strings together ("String1,String2,...,StringN").
    Example: -f "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.num_of_cores","UM_STAT.UM_CPU.ds_status"

    • Statistics ID

      Refer to the "stat-id" value in the output of the "cpview -p" / "cpview --print" command.

      Example Output - Formatted as pretty JSON:

      [Expert@R82:0]# cpview -p -f "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.num_of_cores" | jq '.'
{
  "next-cursor": null,
  "data": [
    {
      "stat-id": "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.num_of_cores",
      "records": [
        {
          "timestamp": {
            "posix": 1730729512,
            "iso-8601": "2024-11-04T16:11+0200"
          },
          "value": 4
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

    • Internal Metric Label

      In the $CPDIR/conf/cpview_api_service_conf.xml file, refer to the values of the "labels=" parameters.

      Examples of Internal Metric Labels:

      • labels="CPU,Dynamic_Split,OS,Configuration"

      • labels="Hardware,Interfaces,Drops,Errors"

      In the CLI syntax, you can use any of these labels - one label or several labels:

      • -f "CPU"
      • -f "Dynamic_Split"
      • -f "CPU,Dynamic_Split"
      • -f "Drops,Errors"
      • and so on

      Example Output - Formatted as pretty JSON:

      [Expert@R82:0]# cpview -p -f "Dynamic_Split" | jq '.'
{
  "next-cursor": null,
  "data": [
    {
      "stat-id": "UM_STAT.UM_CPU.ds_status",
      "records": [
        {
          "timestamp": {
            "posix": 1730736137,
            "iso-8601": "2024-11-04T18:02+0200"
          },
          "value": "Off"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
[Expert@R82:0]#

cpview -s {on | off | stat}

cpview --services {on | off | stat}

Administration of the CPView services that are responsible for the Database and SNMP activity:

  • on - Enables the CPView services (this is the default)

  • off - Disables the CPView services

  • stat - Shows the status of the CPView services

  • export - Exports the current CPView database

Example Output:

[Expert@R82:0]# cpview --services stat
CPView services running
[Expert@R82:0]#

cpview -t [<Timestamp>]

cpview --history [<Timestamp>]

Shows the data in the History mode - either the oldest available data, or the data for the specified timestamp.

In CPview, press the "t" key and enter the applicable date and time.

The <Timestamp> format is:
[Jan...Dec] [01...31] [4-digit Year] [hh:mm:ss]

In versions R81.10 and higher, you can enter a partial date. For example: Jan 02
