assets.raw:
## **Table of Contents** - Overview - ThreatSpect Engine and ThreatCloud Repository - Reputation Layer - Signatures Layer - Suspicious Mail Outbreaks Layer - Behavioral Patterns Layer - Connection Flow - Policy installation - Indicators - Troubleshooting and Debug - General Debug ## Overview **Starting from R80,Â Anti-Bot and Anti-Virus Software Blades are part ofÂ Threat Prevention solution.** To challenge today's malware landscape, Check Point's comprehensive Threat Prevention solution offers a multi-layered, pre- and post-infection defense approach and a consolidated platform that enables enterprise security to deal with modern malware: - **Anti-Virus** - Pre-infection detection and blocking of malware at the gateway. The Anti-Virus Software Blade is continuously updated from ThreatCloud. It detects and blocks malware by correlating multiple detection engines before users are affected. - **Anti-Bot** - Post-infection detection of bots on hosts. Prevents bot damages by blocking bot C&C (Command and Control) communications. The Anti-Bot Software Blade is continuously updated from ThreatCloud, a collaborative network to fight cybercrime. Anti-Bot discovers infections by correlating multiple detection methods. ### Anti-Bot A _bot_ is malicious software that can invade your computer. There are many infection methods. These include opening attachments that exploit a vulnerability and accessing a web site that results in a malicious download. One bot can often create multiple threats. Bots are frequently used as part of Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) where cyber criminals try to damage individuals or organizations. The Anti-Bot Software Blade detects and prevents these bot and botnet threats. A botnet is a collection of compromised and infected computers. The Anti-Bot Software Blade uses these procedures to identify bot infected computers: - **Identify the C&C addresses used by criminals to control bots -**Â These web sites are constantly changing and new sites are added on an hourly basis. Bots can attempt to connect to thousands of potentially dangerous sites. It is a challenge to know which sites are legitimate and which are not. - **Identify the communication patterns used by each botnet family -**Â These communication fingerprints are different for each family and can be used to identify a botnet family. Research is done for each botnet family to identify the unique language that it uses. There are thousands of existing different botnet families and new ones are constantly emerging. - **Identify bot behavior -**Â Identify specified actions for a bot such as, when the computer sends spam or participates in DoS attacks. ### Anti-Virus _Malware_ is a major threat to network operations that has become increasingly dangerous and sophisticated. Examples include worms, blended threats (combinations of malicious code and vulnerabilities for infection and dissemination) and Trojans. The Anti-Virus Software Blade scans incoming and outgoing files to detect and prevent these threats. It also gives pre-infection protection from malware contained in these files. The Anti-Virus Software Blade: - Identifies malware in the organization using the ThreatSpect engine and ThreatCloud repository: - Prevents malware infections from incoming malicious files types (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, PDF, etc.) in real-time. Incoming files are classified on the gateway and the result is then sent to the ThreatCloud repository for comparison against known malicious files, with almost no impact on performance. - Prevents malware download from the internet by preventing access to sites that are known to be connected to malware. Accessed URLs are checked by the gateway's caching mechanisms or sent to the ThreatCloud repository to determine if they are permissible or not. If not, the attempt is stopped before any damage can take place. - Uses the ThreatCloud repository to receive binary signature updates and query the repository for URL reputation and Anti-Virus classification. ## ThreatSpect Engine and ThreatCloud Repository The ThreatSpect engine is a unique multi-tiered engine that analyzes network traffic and correlates information across multiple layers to find bots and other malware. It combines information on remote operator hideouts, unique botnet (a collection of compromised computers) traffic patterns and behavior to identify thousands of different botnet families and outbreak types. ## Reputation Layer Analyzes the reputation of URLs, IP addresses and external domains that computers in the organization access. The engine searches for the known or suspicious activity, such as Command and Control (C&C). The Reputation layer classifies per connection: - IP address - from handle first packet before security rule base. Only in kernel, not in the cloud. - DNS - host from DNS request (for both TCP and UDP) - URL - complete URL from the HTTP request After the discovery of bot infected machines, the Anti-Bot Software Blade blocks outbound communication to C&C sites based on the Rule Base. This classification has 3 stages: 1. First, every URL is searched in the local database, located in _$FWDIR/conf/urlrep.eng_ file that contains some malware data - commonly used signatures, URLs, and their related reputations. Local database is loaded to the kernel, and compiled to one Pattern Matcher (PM) that is executed on the incoming URLs to find a match. If the URL is found there, a response to the client is returned. If there is no match against local database, continue to next Step. 2. RAD (Resource ADvisor) cache (for DNS and URL only), that gives answers to 99% of URL reputation requests. 3. RAD (Resource ADvisor) service in the cloud (for DNS and URL only) If the URL was not found in the cache, a request is sent out to RAD and a response is returned (asynchrony) back to the client, and the relevant data is kept in the cache. Anti-Bot Resource Classification mode for DNS is overridden to "background" on the Security Gateway. These settings override the existing default settings in the SmartDashboard. The Resource Classification settings for Anti-Bot are now configurable from the Security Gateway using the _malware\_config_ file. Using the Security Gateway configuration file provides more granularity and divide classification to DNS, HTTP and SMTP. There are three values for each option: - **hold** - for hold classification - **bg** - for background classification - **policy** - for classification according to Security policy The default values for HTTP and SMTP is policy, but for DNS the default is now _background_. **Reputation tables** - _fw tab -t malware\_cache\_tbl_ - holds hostnames with relevant metadata on the threats related to this host and it sub-domains - _fw tab -t malware\_map\_tbl_ - Map between first level domain (FLDs) to sub-domains that were surfed through that gateway Reputation tables format: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk92264/Reputation-tables.png) - **PM** - Pattern Matcher - **AU1** - meaning that the host and ALL its sub-domains are malicious (the metadata of the malware will be kept in the table). - **GRAY record** - meaning that there are paths of this host/sub-domains which are malicious. The related malicious URLs (patterns) are compiled to PM (pattern matcher). Then, the requested URL is executed on the PM. If there is a match, then the URL is malicious (and the metadata of the matched pattern will be returned to the client), otherwise, the URL is white. **Reputation Debug**Â  Run the following debug on the Security gateway when Reputation fails. For example, when getting "_service error_" log or "_cannot connect to cloud_" or when Reputation test page cannot be displayed. **Reputation Troubleshooting**
IssueTroubleshooting
How to know if the host was found in the local database?

In fw_malware_debug.txt file search for "malware_res_rep_pm_match_cb".
If found - there was a match on the PM of the local database

How to know if the host is in the cache?In rad_debug.txt file search for "rad_kernel_malware_cache_get: key was found in cache - requested_url: , requested_url_len: ..."
How to know if the host in the cache is good or malicious?

In the rad_debug.txt file:

  • If you see: "malware_prepare_response: preparing white response" - this is a good (white) host
  • If you see: "malware_prepare_response: preparing AU1 response" - this is a malicious host
  • If you see: "rad_kernel_malware_pattern_metadata_arr_fill_from_match: total_matches after pm execution: <X> " and if (X != 0) - this is a malicious host, otherwise it is white.
How to know if the host was sent to RAD?

In rad_debug.txt file search for "rad_kernel_malware_cache_get: key was not found in cache - requested_url: <requested url>, requested_url_len: <url length> ...."

How to know if RAD response is good or malicious?

In rad_debug.txt file search for "rad_kernel_malware_pattern_metadata_arr_deserialize: _this->patterns_count =<X>..." (that appears a bit after "rad_kernel_malware_response_kernel_deserialize")
If the number of patterns (X) != 0 - then the host is malicious. Otherwise it's white.

Why do I have the map table?

The map table is used for mapping between the first level domain (FLD) to its sub-domains. The key in this table is the FLD, and its value is a list of sub-domains under that domain that were surfed from the gateway. This table is used by the security service.

What to do if there is no response?
  1. Verify that Anti-Malware blade is enabled.
  2. Check proxy and DNS are configured.
  3. Check that you have connectivity from the gateway to RAD
  4. Make sure the tables are on fw tab -t <table name> - does not return "Table <table name> not loaded: Invalid argument)"
  5. Open debug files, search for [ERROR]
## Signatures Layer Detects threats by identifying unique patterns in files or in the network by using the CMI infrastructure. Local database is located in the _$FWDIR/conf/malware.eng_ file and points to a package fetched in the update process. Signature example: _ctx: 147 ; 'data: "/za/images/threatwiki/pages/TestAntiBotBlade.html", nocase;data: "checkpoint.com", nocase, part:headers;' {name: "CheckPoint - Testing Bot"; type: "Trojan" ; family\_name: "CheckPoint"; enf: 1; confidence: 3; perf: 1; severity: 3; protection\_type: "Home"; stream: 0; act\_type: 2; limitations: none}_ ** Signatures Debug:** Run the following debug on the Security gateway: ## Suspicious Mail Outbreaks Layer Detects infected machines in the organization based on analysis of outgoing mail traffic. The Suspicious Mail Outbreaks layer requires an Anti-Spam License and supported in inspect (detect) mode only. ** Suspicious Mail Outbreaks Flow** ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk92264/Suspicious-Mail-Outbreaks-Flow2.png) - When new connection arrives to kernel, some part of email (in kbytes) is trapped to User mode daemon by_msd_ - mail security daemon - The _msd_ process asks the Commtouch engine for reputation by using _ct_ process _ctasd_ - The Commtouch (_ct_) process checks its cache and if necessary, classifies using service in the cloud **Debug** Run the following debug on the Security gateway: ## Behavioral Patterns Layer Anti-Bot engine. Detects unique patterns that indicate the presence of a bot. For example, how a C&C communicates with a bot-infected machine, when the computer sends spam or participates in DoS attacks. ## Connection Flow ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk92264/connection-flow2.png) 1. On new connection arrival, in the first packet, before the Security rulebase: \- Malware rulebase matches a profile for Anti-Bot and Anti-Virus \- IP is classified by reputation IP address 2. The streaming I/S passes the data to the relevant parsers (HTTP, SMTP, etc.) 3. The parsers call for CMI server \- Pattern Matcher execution \- Notifies the relevant engine / blade Upon engine detection, the Malware rulebase is hierarchically matched (to check if the detected protection is in exception) **Connection Debug in kernel** ## Policy installation **Policy Model** The Anti-Bot and Anti-Virus policy determines how the system inspects connections for bots and viruses. The primary component of the policy is the Rule Base. The rules use the Malware database and network objects. The Blades are integrated with Rule Base. Each rule references to set of configuration - profile, which the connection will be inspected / enforced (by Anti-Bot & Anti-Virus) accordingly. 1. Granular Policy - multiple profile support per gateway, a profile can be assigned to multiple rules 2. Cloud based - the threats / protections in SmartConsole are shown directly from the cloud 3. Separate policy installation - quickly completed and does not affect Security policy Malware database is located in _$FWDIR/conf/install\_manager\_tmp/ANTIMALWARE/conf/_ directory on the Security Management server. Matching malware rule base is done on the first packet handling and saved in the _mal\_conns_ table. This table limit is 25,000. Run the "_fw tab -t mal\_conns_" command to see its content. After compilation the compiled policy is transferred to _$FWDIR/state/\_\_tmp/AMW/_ directory. If the policy installation is completed successfully, the files are copied to _$FWDIR/state/local/AMW/< current policy directory>_. Malware database is asynchronously loaded after separate policy installation is completed. Any failure will be logged, and the status can be monitored in the overview page. **Rule Base Debug** _fw ctl debug 0 fw ctl debug -buf 32000 fw ctl debug -m NRB all fw ctl debug -m fw + malware (_since R80: _fw ctl debug -m MALWARE + all) fw ctl kdebug -T -f > /var/log/debug.txt_ **Debug of Policy installation** **Note**: For better results, run both user mode debugs at the same time. ## IndicatorsÂ  **Threat Indicators** lets you add feeds to the Anti-Bot and Anti-Virus engines, in addition to the feeds included in the Check Point packages and ThreatCloud feeds. An Indicator is a set of observables which represent a malicious activity in an operational cyber domain, with relevant information on how to interpret it and how to handle it.Â This feature is available since [R77.20 Security Management Add-On](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk101217). **Starting with R80.30, see the [Threat Prevention Administration Guide](https://support.checkpoint.com/product/417#f-commonsource=C.%20Documentation) for the relevant version.** **For lower versions, read below** **IOC** - Indicators Of Compromise. IOC Compromise convey an attack campaign by: - specific observable patterns - additional information intended to represent artifacts & behaviors of interest within a cyber-security context **Observable** - is an event or a stateful property that can be observed in an operational cyber domain. For example: IP address, MD5 file signature, URL, Mail sender address. Indicators are derived from intelligence, self analysis and/or governments, partners etc. The goal of Indicator is to give an ability to add private feed into Anti-Virus and Anti-Bot engines, besides Check Point packages update and ThreatCloud feed. It also assist the customers with the operational and engineering management challenges they face handling indicators: Managing, implementing, exchanging and auditing. ### Requirements - Local - the indicators remain only in user's premise - Each indicator is a file with the following information: - Metadata - List of observables and their metadata - Automatic way to add a huge amount of files - Types are - MD5s and addresses (domains, URLs, IPs) - No suppression based on collaboration information (e.g. collaboration with white files) - Up to 260K observables - Action of observable is retrieved from the metadata, profile and policy, just as for the DB of protection of Anti-Malware ### Indicator File Format Each indicator file can be either in CSV or STIX XML format and contain records of equal size. **CSV (\*.csv) format** - Delimiter between fields is ',' - Delimiter between records is '\\n' - Fields are plain text - Each record "must" contain the same number of comma-separated fields - Quoted fields are accepted. - The first line/record, prefixed with â€˜#â€™, is a header containing column names in each of the fields. **STIX - Structured Threat Information eXpression** STIXâ„¢ is a collaborative community-driven effort to define and develop a standardized language to represent structured cyber threat information. For more information, refer to [STIX 1.x Archive Website](https://stixproject.github.io/). ### **Configuration in SmartConsole** 1. User adds his indicator file which can be either .CSV file or STIX formatted file. Refer toÂ [Threat Prevention Administration Guide](https://support.checkpoint.com/product/417#f-commonsource=C.%20Documentation) for more information regarding creation of these files and examples. ToÂ load Indicators, go toÂ Security Policies -> Threat Prevention -> Policy ->Threat Tools -> IndicatorsÂ  2. SmartConsoleÂ does the basic validation for this file, for example it checks that the file is not empty and that CSV file is in the expected format. For example,Â if an optional field is empty, the default value is used.Â If a mandatory field is empty, the Indicator file will not load. 3. When uploading a file to SmartConsole, an XML file is generated for displaying purposes only. 4. Security Management server gives an unique UUID for each Indicator file in the system. Example from R80.20: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc//SolutionsStatics/sk92264/Indicator-r80201901270627.png) Example from R77:30: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc//SolutionsStatics/sk92264/Indicator1708270204.png) ** Code Generation** 1. Prepares IOC metadata as a new _fwset_ object called "indicators". This set contains each indicator's filename, SDB name, uuid, etc. 2. Creates a zip file with all the indicator files themselves.Â  ### Limitations - Observables of IP addresses and IP Ranges can hold IPv4 values only. - MD5 observables cannot be enforced by Anti-Bot Blade. They automatically change to be Anti-Virus observables. If user does not own Anti-Virus blade, there is no enforcement. ### Commands Examples You can run these commands from the CLI (Command Line Interface): `load_indicators --add -a prevent -i CIB-20140210-01.csv --policy Standard` `load_indicators --delete --indc-files -i CIB-20140210-01.csv --policy Standard -f` `Stix_Converter.exe ` `Indicator_Parser.exe -i Appendix_E_MD5s.xml -o output.csv -pid 18446744069414584321` ### Debugging **Debug via SmartConsole** To **_debug an import of Idicator file_** via SmartConsole, run the followingÂ commands from the command line where SmartConsole is installed, under _PROGRAM\\util\\_ directory: ``` C:\Program Files (x86)\CheckPoint\SmartConsole\R77.20\PROGRAM\util>
> set TDERROR_ALL_IOC=5
> Indicator_Parser.exe -i -o out.xml â€“pid 18446744069414584321 > sdb_debug.txt 2>&1
> set TDERROR_ALL_IOC= ``` **Debug via CLI (Command Line Interface)** To debug an import/deletion of Indicator file via CLI, run the following commands from the Security Management machine: ``` > export TDERROR_ALL_IOC=5
> load_indicators -i >& cli_debug.txt
> unset TDERROR_ALL_IOC ``` For example:Â _load\_indicators --add -a prevent -i indicator.csv >& cli\_debug.txt_ ## Troubleshooting and Debug **Check Point ThreatWiki** The ThreatWiki is an easy to use tool that lets you search and filter Check Point's Malware Database. Filter by a category, type or risk level and search for a keyword or malware. - For versions R80 and above, this tool is available at this [online Web page](https://threatwiki.checkpoint.com/threatwiki/public.htm). This link is also located in the SmartConsole: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc//SolutionsStatics/sk92264/ThreatWiki1901270412.png) - In versions R77.30 and lower, ThreatWiki is available in the SmartDashboard in Threat Prevention/Threat Wiki: ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc//SolutionsStatics/sk92264/ThreatWiki.png) ### General Debug **Policy Installation Debug - Security Management side** - **Conversion debug** _\# export INTERNAL\_POLICY\_LOADING=1_Â (â€˜fwmâ€™ command is deprecated in R80. This export will enable it) _\# fwm -d load -p threatprevention >& _ _\# unset INTERNAL\_POLICY\_LOADING_ - **Code generation debug** _\# export LINKS\_C\_DIR=0_ _\# export TDERROR\_ALL\_ALL=5_ _\# amw\_loader -d load -p -d $FWDIR/conf/install\_manager\_tmp/ANTIMALWARE/conf/ >& _ _\# unset LINKS\_C\_DIR_ _\# unset TDERROR\_ALL\_ALL_ **Note**: on MDS environment, use 'setenv' command prior to debugs **Policy Installation Debug - Security Gateway side**Â  - **User mode debug**_\# TDERROR\_ALL\_MALWARE=5 fw -d amw fetchlocal >& _Run the following debug on the Security gateway when policy installation fails with "_Load on module failed_" error: _\# TDERROR\_ALL\_MALWARE=5 fw -d amw â€“d fetchlocal â€“d $FWDIR/state/\_\_tmp/AMW/ >& _ - If the User mode debug shows no errors, the failure is probably in the kernel prepare/commit phases. **Kernel mode debug** _\# fw ctl debug 0_ _#Â fw ctl zdebug + malware >& _ - **Runtime debug** _\# fw ctl zdebug + malware >&_ ___ For additional information refer to - [Threat Prevention Administration Guide](https://support.checkpoint.com/product/417#f-commonsource=C.%20Documentation) for the relevant version - [sk92515 - How to configure Threat Prevention Exceptions in R77.30 and lower](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk92515)[](http://www.checkpoint.com/products/anti-bot-software-blade/)

assets.title: Error Message for IPSec Security Association Negotiation
assets.raw:
## "No valid SA"

**The Error message indicates a failure in the IPSec Security Association negotiations process: specifically a function timeout occurred. The two most common causes of function timeouts are:**

-   A packet needs to be encrypted, but a new IPSec SA needed for its encryption could not be created.
-   A packet needs to be decrypted, but the IPSec SA matching the SPI on the packet does not exist.

During IKE Quick Mode Exchange, the VPN daemon negotiates IPSec Security Associations (SAs) with the VPN partner site. If negotiations fail and the exchange does not complete, the VPN daemon has no IPSec SAs to send to the firewall kernel. The firewall daemon expires the running VPN's state tables entries or does not start a new VPN, since it did not receive the updated IPSec SAs. The expiration triggers this error message.

**The message indicates the SAs expired, but does not indicate the root cause of the problem. Other SmartView Tracker messages, before or after the "sk19423 Error", provide more information about the issue.**

For a more comprehensive discussion, see [sk19423: Error: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information"](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk19423).

## Various Scenarios

There are quite a number of scenarios, in which you may encounter the "No valid SA" error. The scenarios that we have encountered and dealt with are detailed below.

## Scenario 1

**Title:Â _Error: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information"_**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**OS:** SecurePlatform

**Symptoms:**

-   Error in SmartView Tracker: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information".

**Summary:** The message indicates the SAs expired, but does not indicate the root cause of the problem. Other SmartView Tracker messages, before or after the "sk19423 Error", provide more information about the issue. This article discusses troubleshooting encryption errors that spawn the sk19423 message in various configurations.

See [sk19423: Error: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information"](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk19423).

___

## Scenario 2

**Title: _"No valid SA" logs in SmartView Tracker when creating IPsec VPN tunnel with an interoperable device._**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**OS:** All

**Symptoms:**

-   "No valid SA" logs in SmartView Tracker when creating IPsec VPN tunnel with an interoperable device.

**Summary:** The nature of this problem is due to the ability of the Check Point Security Gateway to dynamically supernet subnets to reduce the amount of SA overhead normally generated by VPN traffic. Most third party vendors are inherently static and therefore do not have the ability to understand this dynamic behaviour. There are currently three possible solutions to this problem.

See _Scenario 1_ in [sk108600 - VPN Site-to-Site with 3rd party](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk108600#Scenario%201).

___

## Scenario 3

**Title: _Site-to-site VPN tunnel fails with various error messages_**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**OS:** SecurePlatform, Windows

**Symptoms:**

-   Site-to-site VPN tunnel with 3rd party vendor fails with one or more errors in SmartView Tracker:
-   Error: "Encryption failure: packet is dropped as there is no valid SA"

-   Error: "No valid SA"
-   -   `Error: "Encryption failure: No response from peer"`
    -   `Error: "No proposal chosen"   `
-   "`Invalid ID information`" error in SmartView Tracker when the Security Gateway initiates a Quick Mode.
-   VPN tunnel can be initiated from one side to the other but no return traffic is seen.
-   TCPdump on the external interface shows that UDP traffic on port 500 enters the Security Gateway, but is not routed past the Security Gateway.
-   VPN tunnel becomes unstable after an '`IKE: Send Delete`' packet was sent.

**Summary:** Phase-two Quick Mode failure occurs due to configuration/misconfiguration of VPN/encryption domain for firewalls involved in Site-to-Site VPN tunnels. Typically, this occurs when VPN domain group contains either numerous networks, or numerous hosts from different consecutive networks along with network objects. This article discusses troubleshooting the supernetting issue.

See _Scenario 1_ in [sk108600 - VPN Site-to-Site with 3rd party](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk108600#Scenario%201).

___

## Scenario 4

**Title:** _VPN between Check Point Security Gateway and Cisco PIX fails: "No valid SA"_

**Product:**Â Security Gateway

**OS:** SecurePlatform

**Symptoms:**

-   Error: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information".
-   VPN between Check Point Security Gateway and Cisco PIX fails.
-   SmartView Tracker may display the following error messages:
    -   Error: "Encryption failure: packet is dropped as there is no valid SA"
    -   Error: "No valid SA"
    -   Error: "Encryption failure: No response from peer"
    -   Error: "No proposal chosen"

**Summary:** VPN between Check Point Security Gateway and Cisco PIX may fail because Cisco Tunnel Sharing is configured for host based VPN, while Check Point Tunnel Sharing is usually configured for network based VPN.

VPN between Check Point Security Gateway and Cisco PIX may also fail due to a mismatch in the settings between the two devices. For instance, if the Check Point Security Gateway proposes a network of 192.168.1.X/24, but the Cisco Access list is setup for traffic from 192.168.X.X/16, the connection will fail.

See Scenario 3 in [sk112054: Troubleshooting the "Encryption failure: no response from peer" error](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk112054).

___

## Scenario 5

**Title: _Why do packets get dropped in IPSO cluster with error "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA"_  
**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**OS:** IPSO

**Symptoms:**

-   When running SecureClient / SecuRemote connections to Nokia IPSO 3.7 and CheckÂ Point cluster, the connection is properly established, but some servers in the encryption domain cannot always be accessed. The log shows packets being dropped with the following error message: encryption fail reason: "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in Secureknowledge database for more information."

**Summary:** In the IPSO and Check Point cluster environment, there can be a Quick Mode SA initiated also **from the cluster side** to the SecureClient station and not just from the client side to the cluster. Even though there is already an active IPSec SA, established by the client, the Check Point cluster sometimes wants to establish its own, corresponding IPSec SA. The SA is initiated when a return packet is handled by another cluster member than the one that handled the initial client IKE connection.Â 

If the SA negotiation initiated from the cluster side fails for some reason, a situation can arise where part of the connections to the encryption domain work properly, but part of the connections fail. In this case, the logs show packets being dropped with the above error message.

See [sk40187: Why do packets get dropped in IPSO cluster with error "Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA"](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk40187).

___

## Scenario 6

**Title:Â _Error: "Encryption failure: Both endpoints are in the encryption domain"_**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**Symptoms:**

-   VPN rule result is "Accept" instead of "Encrypt", followed by error: "Both end points are in the encryption domain".
-   Error: "Encryption fail reason: Packet is dropped because there is no valid SA - please refer to solution sk19423 in SecureKnowledge Database for more information"

**Cause:  
**

Two possible causes are:

-   In VPN-1 Power/UTM NGX and above, the Security Gateway's interface is automatically included in its Encryption Domain.
-   If user uses Virtual Interfaces on the Security Gateway, these Virtual Interfaces are also included in the Security Gateway's Encryption Domain, even though they were not explicitly defined as part of the Encryption Domain.

**Solution:**

Â Remove overlapping Encryption Domains, or any Virtual Interface IP Addresses of the Security Gateway that could result in a conflict.

___

## Scenario 7

**Title:Â _Cannot Establish Site-to-Site VPN Between Managed UTM-1 Edge Devices_**

**Product:** Edge

**Symptoms:**

-   Cannot establish site-to-site VPN between two UTM-1 Edge appliances managed by the same Security Management Server.
-   SmartView Tracker shows VPN traffic between sites as dropped due to no valid SA.
-   IKE debugs contain the error "FW\_SECUREMOTE\_NOTIFICATION: Could not agree on common methods. Check that the user is properly defined."
-   Unable to manage device from SmartDashboard.

**Cause:**Â The appliances have lost their connection to the Service Center (Security Management Server).

**Solution:**

Re-connect the UTM-1 Edge appliances to the Service Center.

___

## Scenario 8

**Title:Â _VPN packets dropped with "no valid SA" error, when CoreXL enabled in VPN over a VPN configuration_**

**Product:** CoreXL

**OS:** SecurePlatform 2.6, IPSO 6.2

**Symptoms:**

-   VPN packets are dropped with "no valid SA" error, when CoreXL is enabled in VPN over a VPN configuration.

**Cause:**Â CoreXL is incorrectly passing the decrypted VPN packet to a separate gateway causing the firewall to decide that it should decrypt the second VPN packet.

**Solution:**

[Contact Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html) to get a Hotfix for this issue.  
A Support Engineer will make sure the Hotfix is compatible with your environment before providing the Hotfix.

___

## Scenario 9

**Title:Â _iPhone L2TP connections fail in LS Cluster environment_**

**Product:** Security Gateway

**Version:** NGX R65

**OS:** Linux, SecurePlatform, SecurePlatform 2.6, Windows

**Symptoms:**

-   iPhone (with R65 HFA\_50) L2TP connections fail in LS Cluster environment.
-   Various generic error messages are "Main Mode Sent Notification to Peer: payload malformed - possibly a mismatch in pre-shared keys" and "No valid SA"

**Cause:** NGX R65 HFA\_50 has a bug that breaks L2TP connections.

**Solution:**

iPhone L2TP connections do work in NGX R65 HFA\_40.

Please upgrade the firewall to R70 or Higher. A fix should be incorporated in these releases.

Please also note you may also have to upgrade the Management server to the same version or higher. Check Point does not support having the firewall at a higher level than the Management server.

___

assets.raw:
ProductIPS VersionR80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20 OSGaia, Windows Last Modified2025-03-02 ## Solution ## How to troubleshoot IPS update \[scheduled and manual\] issues If IPS update fails, the user needs to understand what kind of update is being performed, as troubleshooting steps are different for various kinds of update. ### _For manual IPS update issues_ **The client (Windows PC that runs SmartDashboard) is the one that initiates the connection towards the Check Point updates servers, and most troubleshooting has to be performed on the client PC.** In both cases (**scheduled and manual**), the following update server URLs should be reachable by DNS, HTTP and HTTPS (for example can be opened on a normal web browser, e.g. Google Chrome or Internet Explorer). Open the browser on the client that is performing the IPS manual update, and verify connectivity to: - [http://cws.checkpoint.com](http://cws.checkpoint.com/) - [https://updates.checkpoint.com](https://updates.checkpoint.com/) - [http://dl3.checkpoint.com](https://dl3.checkpoint.com/) - [https://secureupdates.checkpoint.com](https://secureupdates.checkpoint.com/) **Notes:**Â  - You might get a redirect to a page, a page with the words "It works!" or "File not found."Â  - A blank page indicates an issue. If there is no connectivity to the above servers, the issue is on the client connectivity side. For example; a proxy issue, routing issue, etc. **If there is connectivity (with or without proxy);** 1. If the update is stuck at 99%, please refer to article [sk111760](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk111760). 2. Verify if HTTPS Inspection is enabled and if "Bypass HTTPS inspection of traffic to well-known software update services" is enabled" per article [sk98655](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk98655). 3. If the update won't start at all, and fails, please collect the following information: 1. Debug SmartConsole GUI client as per article [sk112334](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk112334). 2. Download [WireShark](https://www.wireshark.org/download.html) and install it on the client PC, collect a traffic capture file during the IPS manual update issue being replicated. 3. Provide the output files from SmartConsole debug and traffic capture toÂ [Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html). 1. Collect the following debugs: 1. Â FWM debug form the Management server during IPS update: \# fw debug fwm on TDERROR\_ALL\_FWMAU=5 \# fw debug fwm on TDERROR\_ALL\_FDT=5 \# tail -F $FWDIR/log/fwm.elg > /var/tmp/IPSfwmupdate.txt To disable fwm debug run: #fw debug fwm off TDERROR\_ALL\_ALL=0 2. FWD debug from the Gateway during the IPS update: \# fw\_debug fwd on TDERROR\_ALL\_ALL=5Â  \# tail -FÂ $FWDIR/log/fwd.elg > /var/tmp/IPSfwdupdate.txt To turn off: \# fw\_debug fwd off 3. After replication and debug collect files from: 1. GW - /var/tmp/IPSfwdupdate.txt 2. MGMT - /var/tmp/IPSfwmupdate.txt 1. If any other symptom, [contact Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html)Â for additional troubleshooting. ### _For scheduled IPS update issues_ **The Security Management Server / Multi Domain Management Server (the Management or the relevant CMA) is the initiator of the connection towards Check Point updates servers, and most troubleshooting has to be performed on it.** 1. Since the IP addresses of the update servers are changed according to geo-location, and are very dynamic, make sure that theÂ _/etc/hosts_ file under the Security Management Server does not contain any manual entry for the below servers: - cws.checkpoint.com - secureupdates.checkpoint.com - updates.checkpoint.com - dl3.checkpoint.com 1. Review article [sk98781](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk98781) and make sure that the checkbox for "Automatically download Contracts and other important data" is selected. If it is not selected, do so, and install the policy. Then try the update again. 2. Verify if HTTPS Inspection is enabled and if "Bypass HTTPS inspection of traffic to well-known software update services" is enabled" per article [sk98655](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk98655). 3. Verify that the Security Management Server can reach and resolve the servers, as follows: 1. If theÂ Security Management Server is not using proxy, use: _\# nslookup cws.checkpoint.com_ Repeat the command for all servers and verify thatÂ there is an IP reply. Verify that theÂ Security Management Server has HTTP/HTTPS access to Check Point update servers, using _curl_: (If R76 and lower, ca-bundle.crt is in $FWDIR/bin) _\# curl\_cli -v -1 --cacert $CPDIR/conf/ca-bundle.crt https://updates.checkpoint.com_ _\# curl\_cli -v http://dl3.checkpoint.com_ _\# curl\_cli -v http://cws.checkpoint.com_ **Note:** Possible connectivity errors: Could not resolve host, fetch .crl failed, etc. (these indicate an Internet connection problem). 1. If the Security Management Server is using proxy, use: _\# nslookup cws.checkpoint.com_ Repeat the command for all servers and verify that there is an IP reply. Verify that the Security Management Server has HTTP/HTTPS access to Check Point update servers, using _curl_: (If R76 and lower, ca-bundle.crt is in $FWDIR/bin) _\# curl\_cli -v -1 --cacert $CPDIR/conf/ca-bundle.crtÂ https://updates.checkpoint.com -x _ _\# curl\_cli -v http://dl3.checkpoint.com -x _ _\# curl\_cli -v http://cws.checkpoint.com -xÂ _ **Note:** Change to the proxy IP address and port, removing the symbols. For example, if the proxy IP addressÂ and port is: 10.20.30.40:8080, the command will be: _\# curl\_cli -v -1 --cacert $CPDIR/conf/ca-bundle.crtÂ https://updates.checkpoint.com -x 10.20.30.40:8080_ **For scheduled IPS update:** If all of the above tests were performed and the issue persists, please review and perform _FWM_ debug according to article [sk86186](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk86186), making sure the scheduled update will occur while the _FWM_ debug is running. FWM debug for scheduled IPS update can be run using a more focused debug: _\# fw debug fwm on TDERROR\_ALL\_FWMAU=5 \# fw debug fwm on TDERROR\_ALL\_FDT=5_ To disable fwm debug run: _#fw debug fwm off TDERROR\_ALL\_ALL=0_ If the Security Management version is R80 and up, also debug the CPM process: _\# $MDS\_FWDIR/scripts/cpm\_debug.sh -t IPS\_Update -s DEBUG_ To disable CPM debug run: _\# $MDS\_FWDIR/scripts/cpm\_debug.sh -t IPS\_Update -s INFO_ _\# $MDS\_FWDIR/scripts/cpm\_debug.sh -r_ Debug output files: $MDS\_FWDIR/log/cpm.elg\*. **Note:** Verify that debugs are removed from the _tdlog.cpm_ file. **Note:** In a Multi-Domain Management server environment, the logs for the global IPS update will be in the $MDSDIR/log/mds.elg file, while the logs for every Domain IPS update will be in the corresponding directory in $MDSDIR/customers/, in the fwm.elg file. Collect all files and outputs from troubleshooting steps above andÂ [Contact Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html)Â along with a screenshot of the update issue (Try to include the error that pops-up from the update) For faster resolution and verification, collect [CPinfo](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk92739) files from the Security Management and Security Gateways, involved in the case. #### NOTE This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios. ## Article Properties OriginatorAlmog Sasson Technical ResourceBogdan Kirylyuk Access LevelAdvanced StatusApproved by TAC Date Created2016-07-27 Last Modified2025-03-02 EditorGil Frantsus Last ApproverOmri Morami ## Comments #### Internal only **Important note:Â Prior to using the tools mentioned in this article, make sure you thoroughly go overÂ [sk156153 - Best Practice Guide for Debugging Check Point Products](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk156153).** **For additional troubleshooting steps refer to the following: internal SK's: [sk163540: Troubleshooting IPS or Application Control update issues on the Management Server](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk163540&partition=Internal&product=Application) [sk174903: Application Intelligence \\ IPS Update Failure or Hanging on Multi-Domain Management](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk174903&partition=Internal&product=Multi-Domain).** **Example output showing connectivity, using the certificate, and using SHA-256:** ``` * About to connect() to updates.checkpoint.com port 443 (#0)

assets.title: Check Point Support for Monitor Mode
assets.raw:
ProductAnti-Bot, Anti-Spam, Anti-Virus, Application Control, CloudGuard Network, Data Loss Prevention, IPS, Identity Awareness, Quantum Appliances, Quantum Scalable Chassis, Quantum Security Gateways, Quantum Security Management, Threat Emulation, URL Filtering VersionR77.30 (EOS), R80 (EOS), R80.10 (EOS), R80.20 (EOS), R80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10 OSGaia Platform12000 (EOL), 13000 (EOL), 15000, 21000 (EOL), 2200 (EOL), 23000, 3000, 4000 (EOL), 41000 (EOL), 44000, 5000, 61000 (EOL), 64000, Intel/PC, Power-1 (EOL), UTM-1 (EOL), VMWare ESX, VSX-1 (EOL) Last Modified2025-04-24 ## Solution **Table of Contents:** - Introduction - Support for Security Gateway blades - Support for Cluster - Support for Management blades - Limitations - Important Notes - How to configure - FAQ - Related documentation - Related solutions ## Introduction This articles describes Check Point support for Monitor Mode by various products / blades / features in different deployments. Monitor Mode can be configured on Check Point Security Gateway interfaces and allows Check Point Security Gateway to listen to traffic from a Mirror Port or Span Port on a switch. Monitor Mode on Check Point Security Gateway interface is usually configured to monitor and analyze network traffic without affecting the production environment. You can use mirror ports in the following scenarios: - As a permanent part of your deployment, to monitor the use of applications in your organization. - As an evaluation tool for the capabilities of the Application Control and IPS blades before you decide to purchase them. Benefits of a mirror port include: - There is no risk to your production environment. - It requires minimal set-up configuration. - It does not require TAP equipment, which is much more expensive. Notes: - When enabling monitor mode, anti spoofing and local spoofing should be disabled. - The mirror port neither enforces any security policy, nor performs any active operations (prevent/drop/reject). Therefore, you can only use mirror port to evaluate the monitoring and detecting capabilities of the software blades. - All duplicated packets arriving at the monitor interface of the Security Gateway are terminated and will not be forwarded in any way. - Security Gateway in Monitor Mode does not send any traffic through the monitor interface. Topology: - You can configure a Mirror (TAP) port to duplicate network traffic that is sent to a Security Gateway. - The gateway inspects the traffic but does not drop packets. - Connect the Security Gateway to a mirror port on the switch that duplicates the appropriate ports and VLANs. >
ItemDescription
1Switch with mirror port
2Servers
3Computers
4Security Gateway in monitor mode
5Security Management Server that manages the Security Gateway

Note: Make sure that one mirror port on the switch
is connected to one interface on the Security Gateway.

## Support for Security Gateway blades Monitor Mode is **fully supported** (unless stated otherwise) on Gaia / SecurePlatform OS by the following blades for single Security Gateway deployment: >
BladeComments
Firewall None
IPSThe following will not work:
  • 'SYN Attack' protection (SYNDefender)
  • 'Initial Sequence Number (ISN) Spoofing' protection
  • 'Send error page' action in Web Intelligence protections
  • Client/Server notifications about connection termination
Application Control
  • UserCheck is not supported
URL Filtering
  • UserCheck is not supported
Data Loss Prevention
  • 'Prevent' and 'Ask User' actions will automatically be demoted to 'Inform User' action
  • UserCheck is not supported
  • FTP inspection is not supported
Identity Awareness
  • Captive Portal is not supported
  • Identity Agent is not supported
Threat Emulation
  • Emulation Connection Prevent Handling Modes - "Background" and "Hold" - are not supported (refer to sk106119)
Anti-Bot / Anti-Virus   None
Note: Monitor Mode _is_ supported by Security Gateway VE Network mode. ## Support for Cluster ClusterXL / 3rd Party cluster is **_not_ supported** in Monitor Mode. ## Support for Management blades Monitor Mode is **fully supported** for all Management Blades only on **StandAlone** machine (Management and Gateway on the same machine). ## Limitations These features, Software Blades and deployments are _**not**_ supported in Monitor Mode: - NAT - IPSec VPN - HTTPS Inspection - Mobile Access - Anti-Spam & Email Security - Anti spoofing and local spoofing - HTTP / HTTPS proxy - QoS - Traditional Anti-Virus - User Authentication - Client Authentication - Cluster deployment - Security Gateway VE Hypervisor mode / vSEC Gateway - VSX R65 / R67 / R68 - Gaia Embedded OS (600 / 700 / 1100 / 1200R / 1400 / Series-80 appliances running R75.20.X / R77.20.31 and lower - refer to [sk105380](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk105380)) - SecurePlatform Embedded OS (Series-80 appliances running R71.45) - Setting the value of the kernel parameters "`psl_tap_enable`" / "`fw_tap_enable`" to 1 (one) _on-the-fly_ with the "`fw ctl set int`" command (Issue ID 02386641). - FTP inspection with the Anti-Virus, Threat Emulation, or Content Awareness blade is not supported when Security Gateway works in Monitor Mode (SPAN port). ## Important Notes - When enabling monitor mode, anti spoofing and local spoofing should be disabled. In order to disable address spoofing check: Edit the `$FWDIR/boot/modules/fwkern.conf` file (create it if does not exist) in Vi editor: `[Expert@HostName:0]# vi $FWDIR/boot/modules/fwkern.conf` disable anti spoofing by adding the following line (spaces are not allowed): `fw_local_interface_anti_spoofing=0` - Security Gateway in Monitor Mode must be connected to the Internet (for Cloud-based services - e.g., Social Network widgets and URL Filtering). - Valid license and Contracts file must be installed on Security Gateway in Monitor Mode. - To configure Monitor Mode on **VSX**, refer to [sk88980 - How to configure a Security Policy for Mirror Port Use](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk88980#Mirror%20Port%20Topology%20Configuration) - section "(2) Mirror Port Topology Configuration". - To configure Monitor Mode on a **41000 / 61000 Security System** that runs an R76SP.X release, refer to the corresponding R76SP.X Administration Guide. - To configure Monitor Mode on a **40000 / 60000 Scalable Platform** or **Maestro** that runs an R80SP.20 or higher release, refer to the corresponding R80SP.X Scalable Platforms Administration Guide, or Maestro Next Generation Security Gateway R80.20SP Guide - Chapter 'Deploying a Security Group in Monitor Mode'. - To configure Monitor Mode on an **SMB appliances running Gaia Embedded OS**, refer to [sk112572 - Monitor Mode on SMB appliances running Gaia Embedded OS](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk112572). ## How to configure **Important Note: All steps in this procedure are mandatory.** 1. Enable the Monitor Mode on the desired interface:

In Gaia Portal:

  1. Connect to the Gaia Portal in web browser.
  2. Go to Network Management section - click on Network Interfaces page.
  3. Select the desired interface and click on Edit button.
  4. Check the box Enable.
  5. If the interface has an IP address assigned to it, then remove it.
  6. Go to the Ethernet tab.
  7. Check the box Monitor Mode.
  8. Click on OK button.

In Gaia Clish:

  1. Connect to the command line on Gaia OS.
  2. Log in to Clish.
  3. Enable the desired interface:
    HostName:0> set interface Name_of_Interface state on
  4. If the interface has an IP address assigned to it, then remove it:
    HostName:0> delete interface Name_of_Interface ipv4-address
  5. Enable the Monitor Mode on the desired interface:
    HostName:0> set interface Name_of_Interface monitor-mode on
  6. Verify that the Monitor Mode was enabled on the desired interface:
    HostName:0> show interface Name_of_Interface monitor-mode
  7. Save the changes:
    HostName:0> save config

  4. Choose 5) Network Connections.
  5. Choose 2) Configure Connection.
  6. Select the desired interface that will be connected to the SPAN port on the switch.
  7. If the interface has an IP address, then remove it:
    choose 3) Remove IP from interface
  8. Choose 5) Define as connected to a mirror port.
  9. Press e to exit to the Configure Connection screen of the sysconfig menu.
  10. Choose 5) Show connection configuration

  12. Press e to exit from the sysconfig menu.

assets.title: Emphasize IPv6 Implementation in Check Point Product
assets.raw:
ProductClusterXL, Quantum Security Gateways VersionR80.20.x, R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.10.x, R81.20, R82 OSGaia Last Modified2025-01-05 ## Solution ### Introduction The purpose of this document is to emphasize the IPv6 implementation in Check Point products. The main point of IPv6 feature is that Security Gateway treats IPv6 IP addresses in the same way as IPv4. All commands including debug, are supported with no change and their output contains records for both IPv6 and IPv4 addresses. Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) represents an enhancement of the Internet Protocol (IP), the communications protocol responsible for routing traffic across the Internet. All Check Point Firewall versions support IPv6, with full integration into the Gaia Operating System beginning from version R75.40. This integration includes features such as CoreXL, SecureXL, and ClusterXL, for enhanced performance and scalability. ClusterXL supports High Availability clusters for IPv6. Load Sharing is **not** supported. All IPv6 status information is synchronized, and the IPv6 clustering mechanism is activated during fail-over. Quantum Spark Gateways support IPv6 only in the 1500, 1600, 1800, and higher appliance models. ### **Limitations** - See [sk163313 - IPv6 features and limitations](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk163313). - See [sk174348 - IPv6 Limitations on Quantum Spark Appliances](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk174348). ### **IPv6 Traffic Handling** In releases prior to R76, the firewall did not store IPv6 addresses as actual IPv6 addresses in various tables. Instead, each encountered IPv6 address was assigned a unique identifier, referred to as a "descriptor," which ranged from 1 to 2^32. This descriptor was utilized in the connections table and other internal tables. Every IPv6 packet being handled in the firewall required first finding the matching descriptor (or allocating a new one), which meant more overhead. To make things worst, the table which held the conversion between IPv6 address and a descriptor was shared for all Firewall instances, which meant a shared lock for all instances when accessing this table. All tables contain real IPv6 addresses and there is no difference between how we inspect packets between v4 and v6. The performance is expected to be better as a result. ### ** Performance with IPv6 enabled** Enabling IPv6 support has some performance implications on both IPv6 and IPv4 traffic. More memory is needed for IPv6 versions of CoreXL and SecureXL (Performance Pack), which will reduce IPv4 concurrent connection capacity by about 30% (exact amount depends on available memory). IPv4 packet rate/throughput and connection rate should not be impacted. For a given appliance, the IPv6 connection rate is approximately 40% lower than the corresponding IPv4 rate. Additionally, the concurrent connection rate for IPv6 is about 50% lower than that of IPv4. These discrepancies result from the increased memory requirements for processing IPv6 traffic. ### **Supported IPv6 RFCs** - [RFC 1981](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1981)Â - Path Maximum Transmission Unit Discovery for IPv6 - [RFC 2460](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2460)Â - IPv6 Basic specification - [RFC 2464](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2464)Â - Transmission of IPv6 Packets over Ethernet Networks - [RFC 3596](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3596)Â - DNS Extensions to support IPv6 - [RFC 4007](https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc4007)Â - IPv6 Scoped Address Architecture - [RFC 4193](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4193)Â - Unique Local IPv6 Unicast Addresses - [RFC 4213](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4213)Â - Basic Transition Mechanisms for IPv6 Hosts and Routers - 6in4 tunnel is supported - [RFC 4291](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291.html)Â - IPv6 Addressing Architecture (which replaced RFC1884) - [RFC 4443](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4443) - ICMPv6 - [RFC 4861](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4861) - Neighbor Discovery - [RFC 4862](https://tools.ietf.org/search/rfc4862) - IPv6 Stateless Address Auto-configuration ### Commands On Gaia, all configurations should be performed in Gaia Clish. The output of the **`ifconfig -a`** command lists all interfaces along with their IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, including any configured tunnels between them: ``` [Expert@lab-machine]# ifconfig -a eth0 assets.title: SK92770 - Database Management and VSX Gateway
assets.raw: --- created: 2025-05-05T11:32:32 (UTC -05:00) tags: [] source: https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk92770 author: --- # sk92770 - How to use dbget and dbset on Gaia OS > ## Excerpt > Applies to: Cluster - 3rd-party, ClusterXL, Multi-Domain Security Management, Quantum Security Gateways, Quantum Security Management, VSX (Traditional) --- ProductCluster - 3rd-party, ClusterXL, Multi-Domain Security Management, Quantum Security Gateways, Quantum Security Management, VSX (Traditional) VersionR77.20 (EOS), R77.30 (EOS), R80 (EOS), R80.10 (EOS), R80.20 (EOS), R80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10 OSGaia PlatformAll Last Modified2023-01-06 ## Symptoms - Gaia Database includes corrupted entries. - Entries cannot be deleted from Gaia Database neither when using Clish, nor when using Gaia Portal. ## Solution **Disclaimer:** The `dbset` command should **NOT** be used on VSX Gateway (because it might cause the Gaia database and the Management database to be out-of-sync, which in turn will force the user to reinstall/reconfigure the VSX Gateway). [Consult Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/support-services/contact-support/index.html) before any modification of Gaia database. **Table of Contents:** - Introduction - Changing configuration in Gaia Database - dbget utility - dbset utility - Related solutions ## Introduction - Gaia OS Database is stored on hard disk in the **`/config/db/`** directory: - **`/config/db/initial`** file stores active configuration in plain-text format. - **`/config/db/initial_db`** file stores active configuration in SQLite v3 database. - **`/config/active`** file is a symbolic link to `/config/db/initial` file. - **`/config/active_db`** file is a symbolic link to `/config/db/initial_db` file. The `/config/db/initial` and `/config/db/initial_db` files are updated synchronously and automatically: - In Clish - after running '`save config`' command. - In Gaia Portal - after applying the change (depending on the setting, change might be applied automatically, or user must click on '`Apply`' or '`Save`' button). _Example_: ``` [Expert@HostName]# ls -l /config/ total 4 lrwxrwxrwx 1 admin root 18 Dec 9 14:07 active -> /config/db/initial lrwxrwxrwx 1 admin root 21 Dec 9 14:07 active_db -> /config/db/initial_db drwxr-xr-x 2 admin root 4096 Apr 25 19:55 db [Expert@HostName]# [Expert@HostName]# ls -l /config/db total 312 -rw-r--r-- 1 admin root 37210 Apr 25 19:55 initial -rw-r--r-- 1 admin root 273408 Apr 25 19:55 initial_db [Expert@HostName]# ``` - After machine boots, the Database is loaded into memory. - Each entry in the Gaia Database is separated by a single space, when the left side is called the **prefix** and the right side is the **value** of the prefix. Some lines end with '**t**', which stands for '**true**'. _Example_: ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# grep hosts /config/db/initial hosts:v4:FW2-Member t hosts:v4:FW2-Member:address 192.168.204.12 hosts:v4:FW1-Member t hosts:v4:FW1-Member:address 192.168.204.11 hosts:v4:MGMT t hosts:v4:MGMT:address 192.168.204.10 hosts:v4:localhost t hosts:v4:localhost:address 127.0.0.1 hosts:v6:FW2-Member t hosts:v6:MGMT t hosts:v6:localhost t hosts:v6:localhost:address \:\:1 [Expert@FW1-Member]# ``` ## Changing configuration in Gaia Database The **only supported** way to change configuration in Gaia Database is either in Clish shell, or in Gaia Portal. **Disclaimer:** The `dbset` command should **NOT** be used on VSX Gateway at all (because it will cause the Gaia database and the Management database to be out-of-sync, which in turn will force the user to reinstall/reconfigure the VSX Gateway). In some very rare specific scenarios (e.g., entries in Gaia Database that cannot be deleted using Clish or Gaia Portal), users can use the **dbget** and **dbset** utilities for manipulating the in-memory Gaia Database. **Note:** The `dbget` and `dbset` utilities are **not** officially supported. Check Point cannot guarantee that observed issues can be solved using the `dbget` and `dbset` utilities. **Warning:** The `dbget` and `dbset` utilities bypass the validations performed in Clish and Gaia Portal and also bypass the database configuration lock. Serious problems may occur if user modifies the Gaia Database incorrectly by using the `dbget` and `dbset` utilities, or by using any method other than Clish or Gaia Portal. These problems may require the user to reinstall the Gaia OS from scratch. ## dbget utility **dbget** utility is used to query Gaia in-memory Database. This utility is run in Expert mode: **`[Expert@HostName]# dbget [-iarvcn] [-t transaction_id] [-h hostname username:password] variable`** where: | Flag | Explanation | |------|------------------------------------------------------------| | i | Iterate over entries. | | a | Iterate over all children (with null and non-null values). | | r | Iterate over entries recursively. | | v | Display values. | | c | Iterate over all children that do not have null value. | | n | Display names in numeric order. | _Examples_: - Query the value of the prefix "`hosts:v4:FW1-Member1:address`": ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbget hosts:v4:FW1-Member:address 192.168.204.11 [Expert@FW1-Member]# ``` - Query the value of the prefix "`hosts`" recursively: ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbget -rv hosts hosts:v4:FW1-Member t hosts:v4:FW1-Member:address 192.168.204.11 hosts:v4:FW2-Member t hosts:v4:FW2-Member:address 192.168.204.12 hosts:v4:MGMT t hosts:v4:MGMT:address 192.168.204.10 hosts:v4:localhost t hosts:v4:localhost:address 127.0.0.1 hosts:v6:FW2-Member t hosts:v6:MGMT t hosts:v6:localhost t hosts:v6:localhost:address \:\:1 [Expert@FW1-Member]# ``` These are the contents of `/etc/hosts` file: ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# cat /etc/hosts # This file was AUTOMATICALLY GENERATED # Generated by /bin/hosts_xlate on Thu Apr 25 15:01:11 2013 # # DO NOT EDIT # 192.168.204.10 MGMT 192.168.204.11 FW1-Member 192.168.204.12 FW2-Member 127.0.0.1 localhost ::1 localhost [Expert@FW1-Member]# ``` - Query the DNS servers: ``` [Expert@HostName]# dbget -rv resolv resolv:resolver:1 192.168.36.172 resolv:resolver:2 192.168.36.173 [Expert@HostName]# ``` ## dbset utility **dbset** utility is used to modify in-memory Gaia Database by adding/removing/editing entries. This utility is run in Expert mode: **`[Expert@HostName]# dbset [-t transaction_id] [[-6] -h hostname [username:password]] name value`** OR **`[Expert@HostName]# dbset [-t transaction_id] [[-6] -h hostname [username:password]] -f [filename]`** _Examples_: - Add a new host "`FW3-Member`" with IP address "`192.168.204.13`": ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset hosts:v4:FW3-Member t [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset hosts:v4:FW3-Member:address 192.168.204.13 [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset :save ``` - Change the IP address of host "`FW3-Member`": ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset hosts:v4:FW3-Member:address 192.168.204.33 [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset :save ``` - Remove the host "`FW3-Member`": ``` [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset hosts:v4:FW3-Member [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset hosts:v4:FW3-Member:address [Expert@FW1-Member]# dbset :save ``` - Change keyboard layout (refer to [sk73420](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk73420)): ``` [Expert@HostName]# dbset keyboard:mapping Layout_Name [Expert@HostName]# dbset :save ``` - Change IP address of a DNS server: ``` [Expert@HostName]# dbset resolv:resolver:1 192.168.36.185 [Expert@HostName]# dbset :save ``` - Remove a DNS server: ``` [Expert@HostName]# dbset resolv:resolver:1 [Expert@HostName]# dbset :save ``` - [sk87062 (How to delete entries from Gaia configuration database)](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk87062) ## Article Properties OriginatorYaniv Sagauker Technical ResourceTal Martsiano Access LevelAdvanced StatusApproved Date Created2013-04-30 Last Modified2023-01-06 EditorGil Frantsus Last ApproverMauricio Bracale ## Comments #### Internal only Related **internal** solutions: - [sk38567 (How to use dbget and dbset on IPSO)](http://supportcontent.checkpoint.com/solutions?id=sk38567). ___ **E-Mail thread with RnD:** ``` ----Original Message---- From: VSX Support [mailto:VSXSUPPORT@MICHAEL.CHECKPOINT.COM] On Behalf Of Niv Gafni Sent: Sunday, August 21, 2016 9:48 AM To: VSXSUPPORT@MICHAEL.CHECKPOINT.COM Subject: Re: Conflict between sk92770 and 97998 about using dbset Hi Nikunj, As you said, sk92770 is a general Disclaimer to prevent users from manually managing the Gaia database. In specific cases of mgmt-gw inconsistency, this is the procedure to sync (please note that it is not necessarily the preferred operation). We will review the SK, and think of a better language. It is important to keep it stern, to prevent unexperienced users from modifying the Gaia database, without a good reason. ----Original Message---- From: Nikunj Rangpariya Sent: Thursday, August 18, 2016 at 5:39:00 PM To: VSXSUPPORT@MICHAEL.CHECKPOINT.COM Subject: Conflict between sk92770 and 97998 about using dbset Hi Experts While troubleshooting an issue where Wrp interface shows up on VSX firewall, even after removing it from Smart Dashboard and re-provisioning the firewall, we came across some conflicting information. Looking at sk97998, there is a method (option) to Manually delete the obsolete route and the obsolete interface from Gaia OS database on the problematic VSX machine using dbset. However in sk92770 there is following Disclaimer which is concerning: -------------------------------------------- Disclaimer: The dbset command should NOT be used on VSX Gateway at all (because it will cause the Gaia database and the Management database to be out-of-sync, which in turn will force the user to reinstall/reconfigure the VSX Gateway). -------------------------------------------- I have seen previous cases in my research where dbset was used to resolve such kind of issue based on sk97998. I would like advise on the disclaimer, that does it only apply when there are no issues and Gaia Database and Management database are properly synced ? In our case there is a problematic interface which only shows up on Gaia database on VSX gateway and that is why we want to use sk97998. Or these SKs should be edited to reflect the correct explanation on conflicting information ? Any advice on this is appreciated. ```

assets.title: Troubleshooting Check Point Identity Awareness AD Query Connectivity and Configuration
assets.raw:
ProductIdentity Awareness

VersionR80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82

OSGaia, Windows

Last Modified2024-10-29

## Solution

Using Identity Awareness blade with AD Query authentication method requires several configurations and connectivity tests to be verified in order to make sure it works correctly.

To test AD Query connectivity and/or configuration issues, follow this guidelines:

1.  Make sure that the user defined under the LDAP account unit is a Domain Administrator. If it is not, the user should be defined per article:
    
    -   For Windows 2008 and higher: [sk93938](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk93938).
        
    -   For Windows 2003 and lower: [sk43874](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=skXXXXXX).
        
2.  After making sure the user is defined exactly per the above articles (or as a Domain Admin), the user permissions should be verified. This can be done with 2 tools:
    
    -   **Wbemtest (Windows side test)** - a tool that isÂ used to quickly explore or confirm WMI details, permissions and connectivity, the tool itself and instructions how to run it are described in article [sk91040](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk91040) .
        
        Note: In case of failures with Wbemtest, most likely the issue is related to the user permissions and/or configuration on the Active Directory side, with WMI, and this needs to be checked with Microsoft Support.
        
    -   **test\_ad\_connectivity (Gateway side test)** - a tool thatÂ tests for LDAP and WMI  
        connectivity. Both are needed for AD Query to function. the tool itself and instructions how to run it are described in articleÂ  [sk100406](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk100406) .
        
        **Note:** in case of failures, review $FWDIR/log/test\_ad\_connectivity.elg file, filtering "ntstatus":
        
        `[Expert@Home]# catÂ $FWDIR/log/test_ad_connectivity.elg | grep -i "ntstat"`
        
        Common outputs/issues/error numbers:Â **0xC0000022** - Access Denied,Â **0x00000102** - Timeout reach, etc.
        
        **All values, their explanation and description are described under Microsoft KnowledgeBase:** [NTSTATUS Values](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc704588.aspx)
        
        By using the Wireshark filter **ldap.resultCode == 49**Â  to confirm the credentials set on the LDAP Account Unit are incorrect.Â 
        
3.  After connectivity was verified using both Wbemtest and test\_ad\_connectivity, next step is to understand the status of the DCs connectivity, using:
    
    `[Expert@Home]# adlog a dc`
    
4.  In case there is still an error, validate that the user is indeed configured correctly (Full Distinguish Name is correct), using ldapsearch tool:
    
    `[Expert@HostName]# ldapsearch -h Domain_Controller_IP_Address -D "Full_DN_for_User_used_to_authenticate_to_AD" -w "User_used_to_auth_Password" -b "Base_DN_for_search" "LDAP_Search_Filter"`
    
    **_Example_**
    
    `# ldapsearch -h 10.20.30.40 -D "CN=Administrator, CN=Users, DC=Support, DC=checkpoint, DC=com" -b "DC=support, DC=checkpoint, DC=com" -w "my_password" "(&(objectclass=user)(sAMAccountName=Administrator))" > /var/tmp/ldap_test.txt`
    
    Review the output file underÂ _**/var/tmp/ldap\_test.txt**_ and verify the user has been identified.
    
    **Notes:**
    
    -   If error appears, either the command was not ran correctly, or the username and password are incorrect.
        
    -   If '0 matches' output appears, it means the user is NOT located under theÂ "LDAP\_Search\_Filter", in our case, under Â CN=users, DC=support, DC=checkpoint, DC=com.
        
5.  In case failures still exists, the next step is to debug and capture the logging of the user, to understand what is causing the issue, to do so:
    
    1.  Make sure LDAP account unit was defined, and has a user configured per the above.
        
    2.  Open 1st SSH to the gateway and login to expert mode.
        
    3.  Start traffic capture and Identity Awareness usermode debugs as follow:
        
        `[Expert@Home]# pdp d rotate`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# adlog a d on`
        
        `[Expert@Home]#Â adlog a d extended`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# pdp debug on`
        
        `[Expert@Home]#Â pdp d s all all`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# fw monitor -e "(port(389) or port(636)) and host(X.X.X.X),accept;" -o /var/tmp/ldap.pcap`
        
        **Note:** Replace X.X.X.X with the Domain Controller \[that has issues\] IP address
        
    4.  Via 2nd SSH to the same gateway; re-initialize adlog process to force user login:
        
        `[Expert@Home]# adlog a control reconf;sleep 5;watch -n 1 -d "adlog a dc"`
        
    5.  The screen should show that adlog is reconfiguring, and then after few seconds, it should show the Domain Controller statuses.
        
        **Make sure issue is replicated.**
        
    6.  Stop all debugs and captures on the 1st SSH window with CTRL+C and run the followings to reset the flags and copy the files:
        
        `[Expert@Home]# adlog a d off`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# pdp d unset all all`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# pdp d off`
        
        `[Expert@Home]# cp $FWDIR/log/pdpd.elg* /var/tmp/`
        
6.  [Contact Check Point Support](http://www.checkpoint.com/services/contact/index.html) to analyze the output files and start investigation.
    
    For faster resolution and verification please collect [CPinfo](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk92739) files from the Security Management and Security Gateways involved in the case
    
    Collect the required files:
    
    -   \[**ldap.pcap**\]
    -   pdpd.elg\* \[**all files named pdpd.elg.\***\] from **/var/tmp/**
    -   Mention IP addresses that are relevant for the issue
    -   Outputs of the other tests performed:
    -   **wbemtest**
    -   **test\_ad\_connectivity** output
    -   **$FWDIR/log/test\_ad\_connectivity.elg** file
    -   **\# adlog a dc** output, etc.

**Related solutions:**

-   [sk107156 - Regular Expressions do not work to exclude users from Identity Awareness AD Query](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk107156)
-   [sk105950 - Identity Awareness AD Query fails over VPN tunnel](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk105950)
-   [sk60301 - Identity Awareness AD Query](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk60301)

#### NOTE

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.
