assets.title: Configuration and LSP Group Configuration for Downlink/Uplink
assets.raw:
> **Table of Contents:** > > - Introduction > > - Solution > > - Configuration > > - API > > - History > > - Known Limitations > > > ## Introduction > > Check Point has a daemon that listens to events of ports (downlink/uplink), but there is no way to configure a group of ports that operate as one port. This means that if one of the ports in the group is down, the others must be down, as well, because the ports can only work when all are up (due to the given network topology). If a minimum of one port is down, but the others are up, outages could occur even with the existence of redundancy. > > LSP (Link State Propagation) solves this issue. > > For example: > > Â ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/NEW_SK_NOID1616076809007/LSPSK202103181626551.jpg) > > If traffic flows from client to server, the flow is: > client -> â€˜MHO-1 eth1â€™ -> â€˜eth2 MHO-1â€™ to server > > If â€˜eth2 MHO1â€™ goes down, an outage occurs because we did know from the onset that â€˜eth2 MHO-1â€™ is down. > > The same issue applies if you use the â€˜eth1 MHO-2â€™ interface and the â€˜eth2 MHO-2â€™ is down. > > With LSP, you can configure a group containing these two ports (â€˜eth1 MHO-1â€™ and â€˜eth2 MHO-1â€™) that behave as one port. If one goes down, so does the other, and then the client goes through the ports of MHO-2. > > ## > Solution > > The solution is to configure an LSP group that will be monitored and treated as one port. > > **This feature is integrated into [Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator for R80.20SP Take 313](https://supportcenter.us.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk155832).**Â Â  > > If one of the ports in the group goes down, then all ports in the group will be moved to down so that the switches will not forward traffic for those ports. This eliminates/limits the outage. > > The challenge is to move the ports back up only when we know that all ports in the LSP group are up and working. > > There are two important pieces of information about the ports: > > 1. Ports admin state > - up/down :: configured by s/w > 2. Ports operation state > - up/down :: based on connectivity/auto-negotiation > > ## > Configuration > > The first step is to configure the LSP group(s). > > These groups are saved in a configuration JSON file. The file only includes the ports in each LSP group. > > You can modify the file/configuration on the fly with â€˜clishâ€™ only. > > ## > API > > All LSP commands are under '`set/add/show/delete maestro lsp`'. > > - `set maestro lsp group ports `Â  > - Adds a new group with the given ports.Â  If the group already exists, it overwrites the group. > > - s`et maestro lsp state ` > - Enables/Disables LSP > - `set maestro lsp apply` > - Applies LSP modifications > - `set maestro lsp revert` > - Reverts LSP modifications > - `add maestro lsp group port ` > - Adds port(s) to an existing group. > You can add multiple ports by separating them with â€˜,â€™. > > - `delete maestro lsp group port ` > - Removes port(s) from an existing group. > You can add multiple ports by separating them with â€˜,â€™. > > - `delete maestro lsp group ` > - Removes the entire group and ports from the configuration. > > - `show maestro lsp configuration all` > - Shows the configuration of each group and the state.Â  > If any modifications to the configuration were not applied, they appear in another section. > > - `show maestro lsp configuration group ` > - Shows the ports in the specified group. > If the group has been modified but not yet applied, it shows both configurations. > > - `show maestro lsp status` > - Â Shows the monitoring status of the applied configuration from the daemon. > > - `show maestro lsp history ` > - Shows the recent 'X' events. > X = > > ## History > > The History mechanism shows important recent events that occurred in the daemon on the ports. The events are written into _/var/log/lsp\_history.log_ > > The clish command `show maestro lsp history ` takes the contents of the history log file and orders them in a table. > > The table consists of 5 columns: > > - Time: When the event happened > - Port: The port on which the event has been received > - Event: The event that occurred > - Group: The affected group > - Group Status: The reflection of the event on the group state > > > >
Event (as seen on the CLI)Meaning
DownEvent down was received on the port.
admin-downPort was moved to admin-down. The LSP mechanism forces some ports to go to down (admin-down) in order to manage the groups accordingly.
recovered down->upEvent up was received on port.
moved to admin-down, preparing for group recoveryAfter getting an up event on port, we move it to admin-down, preparing to perform group recovery. We do this in order to minimize the gap between group ports.
moved to admin-upMoved port to admin up. This occurs post preparation for group recovery.
has recovered after <Time in seconds>Port operation state has gone up after X seconds.
found down in initializingUpon configuration loading, we reassess port statuses (initializing LSP). This event states that we have found the port in operation state down.
admin-down in initializingPort has been moved to admin-down because of the event mentioned above.
Configuration change event receivedLSP configuration might be changed on this specific group.
Resetting ports monitoringReassessment of the port statuses (initializing LSP) started (not per port event). 
> > > > ## Known Limitations > > - LSP is on the Orchestrator side only. > - Configuration is not propagated to all Maestro Hyperscale Orchestrators (MHOs). Do any LSP modifications manually.

assets.title: Check Point Maestro Orchestrator Interface Splitter Configuration Not Saved After Reboot
assets.raw:
ProductQuantum Maestro

VersionR80.20SP (EOS), R81.10, R81.20

OSGaia

Last Modified2023-07-19

#### For internal users only

## Symptoms

-   Interface splitter configuration is not saved after you reboot the Maestro Orchestrator.
    
-   The "`# cat /etc/maestro.json | grep qsfp_auto_config`" command returns "on":  
    `qsfp_auto_config" : "on"`
-   The "`# tor_util get_qsfp_auto_config`" command shows "on".
    

## Solution

This problem was fixed. The fix is included starting from:

-   [Check Point R81.20](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk173903)
-   [Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator for R81.10](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/Jumbo_HFA/R81.10/Default.htm) starting from Take 38
-   [Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator for R80.20SP](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk155832#List%20of%20resolved%20issues%20per%20Take) starting from Take 327

If you do not wish to upgrade, disable QSFP auto-config:

1.  Connect to the Maestro Orchestrator.
2.  Enter the Expert mode.
3.  Disable QSFP auto-config:
    
    `# tor_util set_qsfp_auto_config off`
    
4.  Restart services on the Maestro Orchestrator:
    
    `# orchd restart`
    

**CAUTION**: **This restarts all services on the Maestro Orchestrator.**

**Depending on your configuration, the restart could cause service disruption.**

#### NOTE

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.

## Article Properties

OriginatorBoris Ostrovsky

Technical ResourceAnatoly Masover

Access LevelAdvanced

StatusApproved by TAC

Date Created2020-09-15

Last Modified2023-07-19

EditorBoris Ostrovsky

Last ApproverLiron Rubin

## Comments

#### Internal only

It is also allowed to manually modify /etc/maestro.json, but using tor\_util is preferred.

In `/etc/maestro.json`, change the `qsfp_auto_config` setting to off: Â   
`"qsfp_auto_config" : "off"`

Then perform `orchd restart`.

assets.title: Check Point Firewall Logs Show Destination Port -1 and Protocol -1
assets.raw:
ProductIPS

VersionR77.20 (EOS), R77.30 (EOS), R80 (EOS), R80.10 (EOS), R80.20 (EOS), R80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20

PlatformAll

Last Modified2023-01-23

## Symptoms

-   Logs for a host port scan show "`destination port: -1`" and "`protocol: -1`".

## Solution

No fix is required. This behavior is by design.

The value `-1` means "any" or "all" protocols and ports.

**Best Practices  
**

-   Investigate the cause of the logs. Review the firewall logs and identifying the source IP addresses of the connections.
-   Fine-tune firewall settings to block or limit any traffic that is determined to be malicious.
-   Monitor your network for any unusual or suspicious traffic..
-   Make sure there are no false positives for port scanning..  
    For example, if a network device is configured to send certain types of traffic to a specific port, it can appear as if that host is scanning for open ports.  
    Additionally, if a network device is configured to forward traffic to multiple ports, it can also appear as if a host is scanning for open ports.  
    These issues can be caused by misconfigurations, errors, or outdated network configurations.

#### NOTE

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.

## Article Properties

OriginatorEden Bobovnik

Technical ResourceKyle Danielson

Access LevelAdvanced

StatusApproved by TAC

Date Created2023-01-18

Last Modified2023-01-23

EditorEden Bobovnik

Last ApproverRobert Henderson

## Comments

#### Internal only

This is by design in the code.

Generally in the context of network security and traffic analysis, -1 is commonly used to refer to "any" or "all" protocols and ports.  
It is used to indicate that a large amount of traffic is being dropped for multiple protocols and ports.  
In many cases, such as in firewall logs and intrusion detection systems, -1 is used as a placeholder for "any" or "all" protocols and ports when the specific protocol or port is not known or not relevant to the log.  
The use of -1 in this context is a common convention in the field of network security, and is generally known among network administrators and security professionals.

|                HCP-823                 | **NEW:** Added new SD-WAN tests:

SD-WAN - CPSDWAN and Steering Status:  
This test checks whether cpsdwan and steering are enabled. If any of these services are not enabled, the test fails; otherwise, it succeeds.

SD-WAN - Services Running:  
This test ensures that all SD-WAN services are currently running. If any service is not running, the test fails; otherwise, it succeeds.

SD-WAN - Fog Connection:  
This test checks the connectivity between the Security Gateway and the fog through the SD-WAN Nano-Agent. The test fails if there is no connection; otherwise, it succeeds.

SD-WAN - ISP Redundancy Status:  
This test determines whether ISP Redundancy is enabled. The test fails if ISP Redundancy is detected, and it succeeds otherwise.

SD-WAN - PBR Rules Configuration:  
This test examines the configuration of Policy-Based Routing (PBR) rules. It passes with a warning if at least one PBR rule is configured; otherwise, it succeeds.

SD-WAN - Required Files Presence:  
This test checks the existence of all required SD-WAN files. If any file is missing, the test fails; otherwise, it succeeds.

SD-WAN - Software Blades Enabled:  
This test ensures that all Software Blades necessary for SD-WAN functionality are enabled. If any required Software Blade is disabled, the test fails; otherwise, it succeeds. |

ProductQuantum Security Gateways VersionR80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82 OSGaia Last Modified2025-02-20 ## Solution **Table of Contents:** - Introduction - Motivation - Security Gateways and the USFW state - Best Practices - Changing the CoreXL Firewall Mode - Known Limitations - Firewall USFW / KSFW modes and SecureXL KPPAK / UPPAK modes ### Introduction User Space Firewall (USFW) is the infrastructure in which Check Point Firewall instances run in user space mode. **Note** - In VSX Gateways, USFW is the only Firewall mode available. ### Motivation - Improved memory utilization on Security Gateways with many CPU cores. - Improved debugging tools and newly supported features. ### Security Gateways and the USFW state > **Notes:** > > 1. Check Point appliance models that do not appear in the table above, support USFW, but it is disabled by default (CoreXL Firewall instances run in the Kernel Space). > 2. Starting in R81.20, CloudGuard Network Security Gateways have USFW enabled by default. > 3. The FWD process is isolated and affined to a dedicated CPU core, when running in USFW on an appliance with at least 20 CPU cores. > In other cases (KSFW, or less than 20 CPU cores), the FWD process is affined to all CPU cores. > 4. On Check Point 23500 appliances, USFW was enabled by default in R80.30 3.10. It is supported, but is disabled by default in later versions. ### Best Practices > Use the factors listed below to select the best CoreXL Firewall mode for your Security Gateway - User Space (USFW) or Kernel Space (KSFW): > >

Contact R&D (Shai Shabat, Anan Kays). **To get the current Firewall mode, run these commands in the Expert mode:** >
ProcedureInstructions
Recommended

Run these commands in the Expert mode:

  1. cpprod_util FwIsUsermode
  2. cpprod_util FwIsUsfwMachine

Possible output:

  • 0 - KSFW
  • 1 - USFW
Optional

Run this command in the Expert mode:

ps aux | grep -E "PID|fwk"

If the output shows both the "fwk_forker" and "fwk_wd" processes, then the Security Gateway runs in the USFW mode.

Example:

[Expert@GW:0]# ps aux | grep -E "PID|fwk"
> USER       PID %CPU %MEM    VSZ   RSS TTY      STAT START   TIME COMMAND
> admin     5617  0.0  0.0   2652   572 pts/2    R+   18:07   0:00 grep --color=auto -E PID|fwk
> admin    10304  0.0  2.2 204216 177468 ?       SLs  Dec02   0:00 fwk_forker
> admin    10313  0.0  0.1  46592  9200 ?        Ss   Dec02   0:28 fwk_wd -i 3 -i6 0
> admin    10321  0.6  7.3 1789464 582708 ?      S<Ll Dec02  21:36 fwk
> [Expert@GW:0]#
>
**To configure the KSFW mode, run these commands in the Expert mode:** > **Important** - In Maestro, KSFW is supported only in R81 and higher versions. > > 1. _cpprod\_util FwSetOverrideMode 1_ > 2. _cpprod\_util FwSetUsermode 0_ > 3. _cpprod\_util FwSetUsfwMachine 0_ > 4. _reboot_ **To configure the USFW mode, run these commands in the Expert mode:** > 1. _cpprod\_util FwSetOverrideMode 1_ > 2. _cpprod\_util FwSetUsermode 1_ > 3. _cpprod\_util FwSetUsfwMachine 1_ > 4. _reboot_ **23000 Support Question:** **Why does 23000 default show USFW is disabled?** Per R&D (Shai), In general, before we move all appliances to USFW by default, we worked in a method that â€“ USFW will be enabled only for new appliances (aka, lines that were released after USFW was GA). 23500 is not part of that, it was released before that, as such, it was supposed to run in KMFW. In R80.30 there was a bug that prevented this machine to load in kernel mode (static memory was too high and caused the OS to failed loading all instances). As USFW does not suffer from this bug, we released it in USFW. In R80.40, the memory issue was fixed and machine was able to load in kernel mode, as our method was to keep old machines in kernel mode, we moved it back to kernel mode. Hope that was clear â€“ bottom line, there was no issue in USFW, that was just a way to mitigate a problem we had for that machine

assets.title: R82: Check Point's major software release for Quantum products, CloudGuard Network Security
assets.raw:
**R82** is Check Point's major software release for Quantum products and CloudGuard Network Security. It introduces 50 innovative capabilities to strengthen threat prevention, greatly streamline operations and provisioning, and troubleshoot network connections with integrated diagnostics tools.

This release provides access to new AI-powered threat prevention engines that strengthen defense against zero-day phishing, brand spoofing, malware, and more. R82 also adds DNS protection against NXNS, offers DNS configuration granularity, and supports DNS-over-HTTPS Inspection.

Check Point offers the industry's first complete protection for HTTP/3 over QUIC. R82 also enables effortless and automated HTTPS Inspection deployment with granular controls and exceptional performance.

Check Point's VSX has a new versatile mode (VSNext) that unifies management features and APIs across Virtual Systems and physical Security Gateways. Furthermore, cluster management is greatly simplified with a new page in Gaia Portal and a new mode (ElasticXL) that enables Security Gateway clustering without the need for physical Orchestrators.

In addition, R82 introduces a new version of Check Point's operating system with superior networking and routing capabilities. For automation, users and DevOps teams can now execute API calls directly to security gateways through a new dynamic policy layer. For future-proofing, R82 enables NIST-approved Kyber (ML-KEM) encryption to protect todayâ€™sÂ VPN traffic against future quantum computing-based hacking.

These are just some of the powerful new capabilities in R82.

Â Â  Â  ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk181127/ThreatPrevention202409191357592.png)Â  Â  Threat Prevention

> ### AI-based prevention engines
> 
> Check Point's new AI security engines represent a shift in how we utilize data, transitioning from mostly a single indicator perspective to a multi-dimensional approach.
> 
> -   [**ThreatCloud Graph**](https://blog.checkpoint.com/security/introducing-threatcloud-graph-a-multi-dimensional-perspective-on-cyber-security/) - Leverages ThreatCloud AI knowledge base to form relationship graph, identifying attacks patterns to prevent zero-day threats.
> -   **Kronos** - Inspects behavior over time with AI and signal processing algorithms to detect malicious activity, preventing zero-day C2, phishing campaigns and other threats.
> -   [**Deep Brand Clustering**](https://blog.checkpoint.com/security/deepbrand-clustering-an-evolution-in-brand-spoofing-prevention/) - Prevents zero-day brand phishing campaigns with a patent-pending unsupervised deep learning engine. This engine cluster websites into local and global brands and determine whether itâ€™s an attack.
> -   **Dynamic classification of uncategorized websites** \- An AI-based engine for dynamic classification of websites, accurately categorizing URLs to block previously uncategorized dangerous or inappropriate websites.
> 
> ### Improved DNS Security Capabilities
> 
> This release provides new and enhanced DNS security capabilities with the addition of:
> 
> -   **Advanced DNS protection against Non-Existent Domain (NXNS) Attack**.
> -   **Support for DNS over HTTPS (DoH) protocol**.
> -   **[Configuration Granularity](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ThreatPrevention_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001)** \- Advanced DNS Security settings in the Threat Prevention profile.Â 
> -   **Detailed DNS Security statistics** - Now available in the SmartView Dashboard.
> 
> ### Automatic Security Services Configuration
> 
> Zero Phishing, Anti-Virus, Anti-Bot and IPS Software Blades are now more accessible, providing a simpler and easier user experience.
> 
> -   Zero Phishing Software Blade - Introducing a new [**Automatic mode**](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ThreatPrevention_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID003) that significantly simplifies the configuration process, providing a seamless experience. With the Automatic mode, the Software Blade configuration is now effortless: simply enable the Software Blade and you are ready to go.Â 
> -   The Anti-Virus and Anti-Bot Software Blades are now [activated by default](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk182106) in newly created Security Gateway and Cluster objects. See sk182106.Â 
> -   It is now possible to [automatically load and update](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ThreatPrevention_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID005) SNORT rules file as Custom Intelligence Feed and enforce them as new IPS protections.Â 
> 
> ### Web Security
> 
> -   Added support of HTTP/3 protocol over QUIC transport (UDP) for Network Security, Threat Prevention, and Sandboxing.
> 
> ### HTTPS Inspection
> 
> This release [sets a new standard](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_SecurityManagement_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID004) with breakthrough performance, unmatched simplicity, and effortless deployment of HTTPS Inspection. Now, you can significantly increase your security without sacrificing speed or user experience. Embrace cutting-edge technology that transforms HTTPS Inspection into a seamless, innovative solution, ensuring your systems stay secure and your users stay satisfied.
> 
> -   **Enhanced HTTPS Inspection UI** - HTTPS Inspection is fully managed in SmartConsole.
>     -   **Enhanced HTTPS Inspection policy** - A dedicated policy for inbound inspection, including certificate management views for both inbound and outbound policies and enhanced default outbound policy.
>     -   **Trusted CA package** - A new view to manage Trusted certificates and see the status of the trusted CA package.
>     -   **HTTPS Inspection Advanced settings** - A new view to configure advanced settings, including R82 new features.
> -   **Client Side Fail mode** - This new feature automatically detects failures in inspected TLS connections caused by client-side issues, such as certificate-pinned applications. When a failure is detected, the connection is flagged to be bypassed in future attempts, and Artificial intelligence (AI) learns from these failures to identify similar connections.
>     -   **Endpoint Detection** - Identifies endpoints without deployed outbound CA certificate.
> -   **Learning mode**:
>     -   **Gradual & Smart deployment** - Activated during the deployment of HTTPS Inspection, inspecting a minor percentage of traffic over two weeks.
>     -   **Network Learning** - Gathers insights into network behavior and detects potential connectivity issues for Artificial intelligence consideration.
>     -   **Performance Prediction** - Estimates the impact on performance when HTTPS Inspection is fully implemented.
> -   **Bypass Under Load** - Bypasses TLS connections when the Security Gateway experiences high CPU load.
> -   **HTTPS Inspection monitoring** - Introducing the HTTPS Inspection statistics view in SmartView, including bypass/inspect statistics.

___

Â Â  Â  ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk170416/security_gateway_and_gaia202106131341411.png)Â  Â  Quantum Security Gateway

> ### New Clustering Technology
> 
> -   [**ElasticXL**](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) - a new clustering technology delivering simplified operations with a Single Management Object and automatic sync of configuration and software between all cluster members.
> 
> ### Dynamic Policy Layer
> 
> -   [Fully automated, API-controlled policy layer](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk182252) that allows dynamic policy changes to be implemented directly on the Security Gateway in seconds without involving Security Management or installing Security Policy.
> 
> ### Identity Awareness
> 
> -   Quantum Gateways can now use [multiple external Identity Providers](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_IdentityAwareness_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) defined in the Check Point Infinity Portal, providing a cross product unified identity management.
> -   Improved resiliency in case of connectivity loss to the PDP by adding [new Identity Cache Mode for Identity Sharing protocols](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_IdentityAwareness_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002).
> 
> ### IPsec VPN
> 
> -   Added support for ML-KEM (Kyber768) as required by the FIPS 203 standard to address [Post-Quantum Cryptography](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_SitetoSiteVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) (PQC).
> -   [Automatically detect configuration changes](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_SitetoSiteVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002) in AWS, Azure, and GCP public clouds and adjust the VPN settings ensuring connection stability.
> -   Introducing the [Advanced VPN Monitoring tool](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_SitetoSiteVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID003) that shows information on each VPN Tunnel and tracks its health and performance.
> -   [Enhanced Link Selection](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_SitetoSiteVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID004):
>     -   Interoperability:
>         -   Uses public IP addresses as tunnel identifiers to establish separate tunnels for each link.
>         -   Uses Dead Peer Detection (DPD) as the link probing protocol instead of the proprietary "Reliable Data Protocol" (RDP).
>     -   Redundancy:
>         -   Allows redundancy of VPN tunnels including third-party and native cloud VPN peers.
>     -   Granularity:
>         -   Ability to configure the Security Gateway to use different VPN interfaces in different VPN communities. Â 
> 
> ### Remote Access VPN
> 
> -   Security Gateway now [supports the IKEv2 protocol](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_RemoteAccessVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002) for connections from Remote Access VPN Clients (E88.40 and higher).
> 
> ### Mobile Access
> 
> -   Mobile Access Policy and Capsule Workspace configurations are [now available](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_MobileAccess_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) in SmartConsole.Â 
> -   [SAML authentication support](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_RemoteAccessVPN_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) for Mobile Access clients that allows seamless integration with third-party Identity Providers.Â 
> -   New Management API calls for Capsule Workspace configuration. See the [Check Point Management API Reference](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/latest/APIs/index.html) > section "Mobile Access".
> 
> ### Dynamic Routing
> 
> Added support for new Dynamic Routing capabilities:
> 
> -   BGP Extended Communities (RFC 4360).Â 
> -   BGP Conditional Route Advertisement and Injection.Â 
> -   Routing Table Monitor for Event Triggers.Â 
> -   IPv4 and IPv6 Router Discovery on cluster members.Â 
> -   Router Preference and Route Information option.Â 
> -   Route age information.Â 
> -   IPv4 PIM-SSM with non-default prefixes.
> -   IPv4 PIM with BFD.Â 
> -   IPv4 PIM neighbor filtering.Â 
> -   IPv4 PIM RPT to SPT switchover control.Â 
> -   IPv6 Protocol Independent Multicast (PIM) and Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD).
> 
> Added support for new Dynamic Routing API calls:
> 
> -   REST API calls for BGP, PIM, Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD).
> -   REST API calls for Route Redistribution, Inbound Route Filters, and NAT Pools.
> -   REST API calls for IGMP.
> 
> Also see the [Check Point Gaia API Reference](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/latest/GaiaAPIs/index.html) v1.8 (and higher) > section "Networking".
> 
> ###   
> Performance and Infrastructure
> 
> -   [HyperFlow](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_PerformanceTuning_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID001) acceleration of elephant flows for the SMB/CIFS protocol.Â 
> -   HyperFlow acceleration of elephant flows for the QUIC protocol.Â 
> -   Quantum Security Gateway log rate output capacity increased by up to 100% through a new multi-process architecture.
> 
> ### Quantum Maestro, Scalable Chassis, and ElasticXL
> 
> This release features improvements in managing and monitoring Scalable Platform clusters, which include:
> 
> -   Support for REST API:Â 
>     -   New API calls on Quantum Maestro Orchestrator to configure and monitor Maestro Security Groups, Gateways, Sites, and Ports.  
>         See the complete list of available API calls in the [Check Point Gaia API Reference](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/latest/GaiaAPIs/index.html) v1.8 and higher > section "Maestro".
>     -   Support for Gaia REST APIs on Scalable Platform Members.
> -   Support for Gaia [First Time Configuration Wizard](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/Appliances/GSG_Maestro/EN/Default.htm#cshid=ID056) on Quantum Maestro Orchestrators with ability to configure the Maestro Site settings.Â 
> -   Support for authentication to [secure the synchronization connections](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002) between Quantum Maestro Orchestrators.
> -   Support for [SNMP Queries on each Scalable Platform Member](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID004).
> -   Support for [LLDP on Uplink, Sync, and Management ports of Quantum Maestro Orchestrators](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_Gaia_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID163).
> -   New page ["Ports"](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID005) in Gaia Portal on Quantum Maestro Orchestrator. This page shows a summary and interactive view of port configuration, runs diagnostics on ports, and blinks a port LED for identification.Â

assets.title: Connection Tracker: Performance and Reproducing Connection Information
assets.raw:
## How to use the Connection Tracker

ProductQuantum Security Gateways

VersionR80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10

OSGaia

Last Modified2022-09-22

## Solution

**Table of Contents**

-   Overview
    
-   How it Works
    
-   Viewing Collected Data
    
-   Activating and Deactivating Connection Tracker
    
-   Installation of TIV
    
-   Advanced Settings
    

## Overview

Connection Tracker (CT) is used for logging meaningful information related to internal flows execution. It can help investigating connectivity and latency issues without the need to reproduce them.

Due to huge amount of traffic processed by the Security Gateway, in a case of system misbehavior like delay in connection processing, itâ€™s not easy to locate the exact reason causing it.

Connection Tracker identifies on the fly all potential anomalies and persists minimal amount of relevant information that can help to identify, reproduce and resolve system misbehavior issue without impacting overall system performance.

The collected information can help you to:

-   identify scenarios that cause system misbehavior
-   investigate connectivity/latency issueÂ 
-   useful for flow comparison
-   identify multi layer complexity issues
-   reproduce the scenarios
-   resolve the source issues

Notes:

1.  CT is available only on a kernel that runs on the user space.
2.  CT operates on the level of connection and therefore cannot be applied to the cases when packet flow is terminated before reaching the level of connection creation.

## How it Works

CT is working in background, upon connection termination CT analyses collected information (logged tracking points) and takes one of the following steps:

if all logged data is considered as normal, the connection record is is not stored.  
if logged data contains indications of an abnormal behavior (errors, latency, etc), the connection record is stored.

In addition, Connection Tracker supports persisting all records answering user defined filter. The user defined filter requires manual activation/deactivation and may impact the performance.

## Viewing Collected Data

The log files are located under $FWDIR/log/.  
In a VSX environment, the files are located under $FWDIR/log/CTX/CTX0000<VS\_ID>, for each VS.

tracker.log - the log file to which the Security Gateway currently writes logs

You can open log files in two ways:

-   with the TIV tool
-   directly from the Security Gateway. For this, run $FWDIR/Python/bin/python3.7 $FWDIR/scripts/tracker\_parser.py <LOG-FILE>

The connection data collected by the Connection Tracker is outputted in the compressed format. It can be viewed using the TAC Info Viewer tool (TIV).

**To use TIV:**

1.  Open TIV.Â 
2.  Drag and drop _trackerN.log_ into the TIV window.Â 
3.  See the decompressed and translated report.

This is how the TIV for a tracker log file looks like.  
Â  ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk174043/CT202107181451561.png)  
![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk174043/CT202107181455561.png)

In this CT record we can see collected data during the connection life cycle.

The first section is the header, which include general information on the connection -

-   Source IP
-   Destination IP
-   Starts timestamp(TS)
-   End TS
-   Num Points - the number of the collected points on the connection,Â 
-   Flags - filter flags triggered the record
-   Irregular Point Index - the collected point that marked as irregular (ERROR/WARNNING)
-   Protocol
-   Resource

The second section is details on each tracking point. In this record we can see a connectivity issue in the highlighted line caused by certificate issue. Each product associated to point ID, in this case we can see that the error is in HTTPSi product.

## Activating or Deactivating Connection Tracker

Starting from version R81.10, the Connection Tracker is enabled by default. For R81, R80.40 and R80.30 Gogo the Connection Tracker is enabled by default starting:

R81 Jumbo Hotfix Take 42  
R80.40 Jumbo HotfixÂ Take 150  
R80.30 Jumbo HotfixÂ Take 241

In previous versions, you have to activate the CT manually.Â 

**To activate or deactivate the CT:**

1.  Connect to the Security Gateway.
2.  Edit _$FWDIR/modules/fwkern.conf_Â  or create the file if it does not exist.
3.  Add the following line:Â 
    -   _fwconn\_tracker\_enable\_app\_opaque=0/1_  
        where **0** \- deactivated, **1** \- activated
4.  Reboot.

For a VSX Security Gateway, CT is activated/deactivated by a different parameter (see **Configuration Parameters** below).

##   
Installation of TIV \[TACInfo Viewer\]

1.  Download the TAC Tools Manager from [https://tactools.ad.checkpoint.com/home](https://tactools.ad.checkpoint.com/home).
2.  Install the latest version.
    1.  Open the TAC Tools Manager.
    2.  Click the **Install in TIV** icon.
3.  If needed, update the _tracker\_repository.json_:
    1.  Open the TAC Tools Manager.
    2.  Click the sandwich menu button (next to the Open button) for TIV icon.
    3.  Select **Go to Folder**; the JSON file is under _config\\tracker\_repository.json_. If the JSON file is not up-to-date, you can see the points with â€œundefinedâ€ description in TIV.

##   
Advanced Settings

**Setting User-Defined Filter:**  
To record to the file specific connections tracking, enable specific filters and set kernel parameters.

Example:  
Enable specific connection tracking:  
_fw ctl set str fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_src\_addr\_ip 1.1.1.1_  
_fw ctl set str fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_dst\_addr\_ip 20.20.20.20_  
_fw ctl set int fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_enable Â 1_

Disable tracking:  
_fw ctl set int fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_enable Â 0_

|                **Name**                |           **Type**           | **Set via** | **Requires reboot** |                                                                          **Description**                                                                          |   **Default**   |
|------------------------------------|--------------------------|---------|-----------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------|
| fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_src\_addr\_ip | String (IP - host order) | _fw ctl_  |       No        | Write/Persist connections matching the source IP.  
If not set, all source IPs are treated as matching criteria. | empty (all) |
| fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_dst\_addr\_ip | String (IP - host order) | _fw ctl_  |       No        | Write/Persist connections matching the source IP.  
If not set, all source IPs are treated as matching criteria. | empty (all) |
|    fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_sport    |         Integer          | _fw ctl_  |       No        | Write/Persist connections matching the source IP.  
If not set, all source IPs are treated as matching criteria. |   0 (all)   |
|    fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_dport    |         Integer          | _fw ctl_  |       No        | Write/Persist connections matching the source IP.  
If not set, all source IPs are treated as matching criteria. |   0 (all)   |
|    fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_proto    |         Integer          | _fw ctl_  |       No        | Write/Persist connections matching the IP protocol.  
Protocols are coded according to IANA.  
If not set, all source ports are treated as matching criteria. |   0 (all)   |
|    fwconn\_tracker\_udf\_max\_time     |         Integer          | _fw ctl_  |       No        |                                                       Write connections that lifetime are bigger than X                                                       |    1200     |
|   fwconn\_tracker\_filter\_enable    |      Integer Â (0/1)      | _fw ctl_  |       No        |                                                                   Enable/Disable the filter                                                                   | 0 (disable) |

**Notes:  
**

1.  Filters will only affect connections that were established after the filters were set.
2.  Filters for IP/port/protocol (first 5 rows) Â - value 0 means "Any", but if all of them are 0, then it means that the filter is not active.

**Configuration Parameters:**

|                **Feature**                |                 **Name**                  |     **Type**      |           **Set via**            | **Requires reboot** |                                                    **Description**                                                    |      **Default**      |
|---------------------------------------|---------------------------------------|---------------|------------------------------|-----------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------|
| Activation/Deactivation (not for VSX) |   fwconn\_tracker\_enable\_app\_opaque    | Integer (0/1) |         _fwkern.conf_          |       Yes       |                                 Activates/Deactivate the entire feature (not VSX)                                 |   1 (Activated)   |
|    Activation/Deactivation for VSX    | fwconn\_tracker\_enable\_app\_opaque\_vsx | Integer (0/1) |         _fwkern.conf_          |       Yes       |                              Activates/Deactivate the entire feature in VSX Machine                               |  0 (Deactivated)  |
|         Temporary suspending          |       fwconn\_tracker\_suspended        | Integer (0/1) | _fw ctl_  
_(fw â€“vs <vsid> ctl)_ |       No        | Temporary suspends/resumes the tracking feature in runtime. Applicable only if feature is configured as activated | 0 (Not suspended) |
|            Sample logging             |   fwconn\_tracker\_test\_random\_param    |    Integer    | _fw ctl_  
_(fw â€“vs <vsid> ctl)_ |       No        | Defines a random range for unconditional connection logging.  
Setting to 1 means all connections are logged. |       10000       |

#### NOTE

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.

assets.title: Check Point VSX TCPdump Doesn't Show ICMP Traffic Between Virtual Systems
assets.raw:
ProductVSX (Traditional)

VersionR80.30 (EOS), R80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82

OSGaia

Last Modified2025-01-21

## Symptoms

-   Output of the TCPdump tool on the Virtual Switch's Wrp interfaces does not show ICMP traffic in this scenario:
    
    1.  Virtual System "A" is connected to a Virtual Switch
    2.  Virtual System "B" is connected to the same Virtual Switch
    3.  ICMP traffic passes through Virtual System "A", through this Virtual Switch, to the Virtual System "B"
    
    Example topology:
    
    \--- \[VS "A"\] (wrpj1) -- (wrp1) \[VSW\] (wrp2) -- (wrpj2) \[VS "B"\] ---
    
-   Output of the FW Monitor shows ICMP requests on the Virtual Switch's Wrp interface.
    

## Cause

This behavior is by design. There is a feature called Warp-jump which allows SecureXL to accelerate traffic between Virtual Systems. As a result, the TCPdump tool does not "see" these packets.

## Solution

Available options:

-   Use the "fw monitor" command.
-   Use the "tcpdump" on the Virtual System interfaces.
-   Use the "tcpdump" on the physical interface, to which the Virtual Switch is connected.

#### NOTE

assets.raw:
ProductQuantum Maestro

VersionR81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20

Last Modified2025-01-22

#### For internal users only

## Symptoms

-   The WebUI of the Maestro Orchestrator displays the names of some Security Group Members in a Maestro Security Group as "NA" instead of the name of the appliance model.
    
      
    ![](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/sc/SolutionsStatics/sk182333/appliance_name202405251404031.jpg)

## Cause

The **`original_name`** field is missing from the `**/etc/appliance_config.xml**` file on the problematic Security Group Members. This issue might occur after you install a Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator.

Below is an example comparing the good and bad `appliance_config.xml` files for a 6800 appliance.

`[Expert@HOSTNAME:0]# diff appliance_config.xml_good appliance_config.xml_bad`

`1,3c1,3`

`< <model manufacturer="CheckPoint" type="QM-30-00">`

`< Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  **<name>Check Point Maestro</name>**`

`< Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  **<series>Maestro</series>**`

`---`

`> Â  Â  Â  <model manufacturer="CheckPoint" type="QL-25-00">`

`> Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  **<name>Check Point 6800</name>**`

`> Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  **<series>6000 Appliances</series>**`

`580c580`

`< Â  Â  Â  **<smo/><original_name>Check Point 6800</original_name></model>**`

`---`

`> Â  Â  Â  </model>`

## Solution

Do these instructions to fix the problematic field in the `**/etc/appliance_config.xml**` file of the applicable Security Group Members.

1.  Connect to the command line on the Security Group.
2.  Log in to the Expert mode and go to the Security Group Member with the incorrect display name:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# member <Member_ID>`
    
3.  Back up the current file:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]#Â cp -v /etc/appliance-config.xml{,_BKP}`
    
4.  Examine the current values of the applicable fields.
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/name -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `Check Point 6800`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/series -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `6000 Appliances`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/original_name -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `Path doesn't exist or value is empty`
    
5.  Update the applicable fields manually:

1.  If the Security Group with the problematic Security Group Member includes a Security Group Member with a good `appliance_config.xml` file, and the appliance models are the same, then copy the file to overwrite the file on the problematic Security Group member.
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# scp -p admin@1_1:/etc/appliance_config.xml /etc/appliance_config.xml`
    
2.  If the WebUI of the Maestro Orchestrator displays all Security Group Members as `NA`, then update the applicable fields manually:

1.  Update **`name`**:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -u /model/name -v "Check Point Maestro" -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`
    
2.  Update **`series`**:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -u /model/series -v "Maestro" -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`
    
3.  Add the missing fields `**smo**` and `**original_name**`:  
    **Note:** Change the value "`Check Point 6800`" to the actual appliance model.
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -i /model -n smo -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -i /model -n original_name -v "Check Point 6800" -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`
    
    The end of the file should look like this:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# grep original_name /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    Â  Â  Â  Â `<smo/><original_name>Check Point 6800</original_name></model>`  
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]#`
    

7.  Make sure the applicable fields are correct:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/name -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `Check Point Maestro`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/series -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `Maestro`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# xmlt -g /model/original_name -f /etc/appliance_config.xml`  
    `Check Point 6800`
    
8.  Restart the `smartd` service:
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# service smartd stop`
    
    `[Expert@HostName-ch0x-0x:0]# service smartd start`
    
9.  Log in the WebUI of the Maestro Orchestrator and refresh the **Orchestrator** page.Â

### Introduction

Check Point has successfully gained a Common Criteria EAL4+ AVA\_VAN.4 certification for R82 Security Management, Security Gateway, and Maestro Orchestrator.

The certification was performed under the authority of the German certification scheme. The Certificate, Certification Report, and Security Target are available below, and are officially published on the [BSI web site](https://www.bsi.bund.de/EN/Themen/Unternehmen-und-Organisationen/Standards-und-Zertifizierung/Zertifizierung-und-Anerkennung/zertifizierung-und-anerkennung_node.html) and the [Common Criteria Portal](https://www.commoncriteriaportal.org/index.cfm) (at the top, click "Certified Products" > in the "Filter by" section, in the leftmost vendor field, select "Check Point Software Technologies Ltd.").

###   
Documentation

The Target of Evaluation (TOE) is fully described in the Security Target, and includes claims for:

-   Firewall.
-   IPS Blade Pattern Matcher.
-   REST API.
-   Supported non-TOE appliances include:
    -   Quantum Security Gateway.
    -   Security Management Server on a Smart-1 appliance.
    -   Maestro Hyperscale Orchestrator.The full list of supported appliances is provided in the Security Target document.

  

###   
Downloads

The Common Criteria release can be downloaded here:

This article provides a structured approach to troubleshooting, starting with an environment check to baseline expected performance, followed by a basic health check to identify any immediate concerns. Detailed investigation flows and performance metrics are then used to pinpoint specific areas of stress within the system, and guide you through the steps necessary to identify and address the root cause of latency, packet loss, and other performance bottlenecks.Â  **Note:** IPv4 and IPv6 traffic are not combined in all metrics nor are both reported with one command.Â  Please pay attention to which commands or reports only reflect IPv4 data by default. If customer uses dual stack, then run specific IPv6 commands if all IPv4 metrics look acceptable. ## 1\. Setup & Environment check > To try to locate the problem we first need to understand the expected behavior. Therefore, the first thing to do when we approach any environment is to establish its baseline: What is the expected behavior? > > #### Sizing the environment: > > - Hardware (e.g., 5000, 16000) > - Policy and security blades (e.g., NGTP, IPS, HTTPS) > - Blend of traffic (e.g., DNS, IPSEC, HTTPS, IPv4 or IPv6) > - Version (e.g., R80.10, R81.20) > - Kernel version (e.g., 2.6.18, 3.10) > - Firewall version (e.g., kernel/user space) > - CoreXL Instances (IPv4 and/or IPv6)Â  > - Configuration (e.g., Cluster, SA, ...) > > #### Expected throughput: > > Sizing the machine by hardware, version, firewall version, policy and blend - [Appliance Sizing Tool](https://usercenter.checkpoint.com/usercenter/portal/media-type/html/role/usercenterUser/page/default.psml/js_pane/PricingToolsId,AST) > > **Note**: This is only available for users with PartnerMap access.Â  > > #### Change in traffic: > > We do the following to view the machine's throughput history and check if the customer had a recent significant increase in traffic/connections: > > - cpview\_history (1 month prior if enabled): > - `cpview (-t) -> Network (Traffic rate/Concurrent connections)` > - `Note: many windows in cpview_history only report IPv4 data.` > - cpdiag (1 year prior if enabled): > - Internal diagnostics server (BeeDrill) > - Check traffic in cpdiag under tables: > - 'cpview\_fw\_network\_stats\_traffic\_rate' > - 'cpview\_fw\_network\_stats\_concurrent\_conns' > > #### Expected packet handling flows: > > Expected flows by policy and blend > > Examples: > > - Firewall Only & VPN blades â†’ Accelerated Path/SecureXL > - APCL/URL Filtering â†’ Â PSLXL > - QoS â†’ Â QoS inbound/outbound > - IPS â†’ Â All over (depending on Basic/Optimized/Strict profile for IPS) > - Threat Prevention (not including IPS) â†’ Â PSLXL, CPASXL > - Mobile Access VPN â†’ F2F > - HTTPS Inspection â†’ Â CPASXL + Process space load from wstlsd/pkxld daemons > > How to? > > - Check activated blades using the '`enabled_blades`' command > - Check traffic distribution in section (refer to section 4.3.1 below: "Traffic distribution & Acceleration) > - CoreXL assignments: Â `cpconfig -> corexl -> view settings` then `fw ctl multik stat` and `fw6 ctl multik stat` to determine which cores are assigned to IPv4 vs IPv6. ## 2\. Basic Health Check > Once we establish a good understanding of the customer environment's expected performance, we do a basic health check. > > #### Network health and frame loss: > > - Check frame loss by pinging through the Firewall: > - `Gaia/Linux: ping -s 1400 129.82.102.32` > - `Windows: ping -l 1400 129.82.102.32` > - Check interface stability, Look for a nonzero "carrier" value: > - `ifconfig -a` > - Check sync network health, which can cause high Firewall instance load: > - `cphaprob syncstat` > - KPI: >1% packets lost/re-transmitted > - Netstat test: > - `netstat -ni | grep -v "\."` > - Check: > - RX-DRP: This should be < 0.1%. If RX-OVR is the same as RX-DRP, it just means RX-DRP. > - RX-ERR: This should be near zero and not actively incrementing, physical network problem.Â  > - Fiber interfaces with errors can be investigated further: > - Kernel 3.10: using Â ethtool -m (interfacename) > - Kernel 2.6.18: using mii-diag -g (interfacename) > - SW drops (refer to section 4.8 below) > > #### System stability: > > - Cluster failures: > - `cphaprob state` > - Is the cluster stable?Â  When was the last failover? assets.title: Check Point CME Upgrade Failure Troubleshooting
assets.raw:
ProductMulti-Domain Security Management, Quantum Security Management

VersionR80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20

Last Modified2024-02-19

#### For internal users only

## Symptoms

-   You receive a `"step Install Hotfix Action verification failed"` error when running CME upgrade with installation script on Management HA environment, and the upgrade fails.
    
-   A CME upgrade with the Offline package procedure based on [sk157492](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk157492) fails.
    
-   Review of the log in _/opt/CPInstLog/AutoUpdateLogs/CME_ shows installation fails with this message:  
    `Error: Action Install Bundle Action aborted: step Install Hotfix Action verification failed`
    
-   Happens for CME package online or for offline installation.

## Cause

A RPM installation fails, causing the CME installation to fail.

Issue only relevant for machines running with last Deployment installer take 26.Â 

## Solution

To verify the component version on the machine, run the following command in Expert mode:

`# cpvinfo /opt/CPDepInst/latest/bin/da_installer`

The issue will be resolved in next Deployment installer take release.Â 

**To upgrade the CME, use the following workaround:**

Revert the CME installation and install the new CME package manually.Â 

1.  To revert the current CME package run:
    
    `# autoupdatercli revert-completely CME`
    
2.  Install the new package manually or run â€œ`autoupdatercli stop`â€ to restart the autoupdate process and run the installation again. For details refer to [sk157492.](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk157492)Â 
    

**Note:** You can safely revert the CME. It does not delete the current configuration.

#### NOTE

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.

assets.title: RMA: Failed Orchestrator and Quantum Maestro
assets.raw:
**Table of Contents:** - Important Notes - Procedure for Orchestrators R82 - Failed Orchestrator is still accessible - Procedure for Orchestrators R82 - Failed Orchestrator is not accessible - Procedure for Orchestrators R81.20, R81.20 Jumbo Hotfix (all Takes), or R81.10 Jumbo Hotfix Take 61 (and higher) - Procedure for Orchestrators R81.10, or R81.10 Jumbo Hotfix Take 55 (and lower) - Procedure for Orchestrators R80.20SP - Failed Orchestrator is still accessible - Procedure for Orchestrators R80.20SP Jumbo Hotfix Take 309 (and lower) - Failed Orchestrator is not accessible - Revision History Follow the steps below to replace (RMA) a failed Quantum Maestro Orchestrator. ### Important Notes - We recommend to schedule a maintenance window. - In a Dual Site deployment, do the RMA procedure on the Site that is the Standby Site at the time of replacement. If the Orchestrator fails on Site # 1 and this Site was active, you must failover to Site # 2 and make it Active, with Site # 1 as the Standby. Then continue with the RMA procedure. The procedure below uses these Orchestrator IDs: - ID of the Orchestrator that continues to work - 1\_1 - ID of the Orchestrator that failed - 1\_2 ### Procedure for Orchestrators that run the R82 version - when the failed Orchestrator is still accessible Show / Hide this section **Important Note - It is not supported to import a backup file from another working Orchestrator. This procedure requires a backup file from the failed Orchestrator.** 1. On the failed Orchestrator, stop the Orchestrator service: 1. Connect to the command line on the failed Orchestrator. 2. Log in to the Expert mode. 3. Stop the service: 2. If previously you configured the authentication between Orchestrators, then on each working Orchestrator you must revoke the authentication with the failed Orchestrator. See the [R82 Scalable Platforms Administration Guide](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002) > Chapter "**Working with Quantum Maestro**" > Section "**Authentication between Maestro Orchestrators**". You can revoke the authentication in Gaia Portal (recommended) or in CLI (Gaia Clish, or Expert mode). 3. On the failed Orchestrator, create the Gaia backup (it contains the Maestro configuration): **Critical Note** - On the replacement Orchestrator, you must import this Gaia backup file that contains the most recent Security Group configuration. You can create this Gaia backup in Gaia Portal (recommended) or in Gaia Clish. - To create this Gaia backup in Gaia Portal: 1. With a web browser, connect to the failed Orchestrator: `https://` Log in with the username "`admin`" and the corresponding password. 2. Go to **Maintenance** > **System Backup**. 3. Click **Backup** > select **This appliance**. 4. Click **Export** to download this Gaia backup file to your computer. - To create this Gaia backup in Gaia Clish: 1. Connect to the command line on the failed Orchestrator. 2. Log in to Gaia Clish. 3. Create a local Gaia backup: 4. Copy the Gaia backup file from the failed Orchestrator: 1. Connect with WinSCP to the failed Orchestrator. **Important Note** - Refer to [sk42178](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk42178) to make sure this SCP connection works. 2. Go to this path: `/var/log/CPbackup/backups/` 3. Download the Gaia backup file to your computer. 4. On the failed Orchestrator, write down the port numbers, to which the **Uplink** cables, the **Downlink** cables, and the **Sync** cables are connected. 5. On the failed Orchestrator, disconnect all network cables and the power cables. 6. Remove the failed Orchestrator from the rack. 7. Install the replacement Orchestrator **of the same model** in the rack. **Important Note** - Do **not** connect the power or network cables yet. You do it gradually later. 8. On the replacement Orchestrator, connect only these cables: See the [Quantum Maestro Getting Started Guide](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/Appliances/GSG_Maestro/EN/Default.htm). 1. Connect a network cable from your computer to the Orchestrator's "**MGMT**" port. 2. Connect the console cable from your computer to the Orchestrator's **Console** port. In your console client application, configure these settings: - Baud Rate - 9600 - Data bits - 8 - Stop bits - 1 - Parity - None - Flow Control - None 3. Connect the power cables to the Orchestrator's Power Supply Units. 9. On the replacement Orchestrator, in the **console** session, log in to Gaia Clish. **Important Note** - Do **not** perform the First Time Configuration Wizard yet. 10. On the replacement Orchestrator, configure the Orchestrator's "**MGMT**" port: 1. Configure the IPv4 address and Mask Length: `set interface Mgmt1 ipv4-address mask-length ` 2. Enable the "MGMT" port: `set interface Mgmt1 state on` 3. Configure the default gateway: `set static-route default nexthop gateway address on` 4. Save the changes: For information about these Gaia Clish commands, see the [R82 Gaia Administration Guide](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_Gaia_AdminGuide/Default.htm). 11. On the replacement Orchestrator, connect these cables to ports with the same numbers as they were connected on the failed Orchestrator: - The **Downlink** cables - The **Sync** cables **Important Note** - Make sure you connected the cables to the correct ports. 12. On the replacement Orchestrator, run the First Time Configuration Wizard: **Important Note** - Do **not** import the backup file from the failed Orchestrator. You must do it later. 1. With a web browser, connect to the replacement Orchestrator: `https://` Log in with the username "`admin`" and the default password "`admin`". 2. On the second page **Deployment Options**, select **Join an existing Maestro environment**. 3. Follow the rest of the wizard pages. 4. Wait for the Orchestrator to reboot. 13. On the replacement Orchestrator, install the same Take of the **R82 Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator** as installed on **working** Orchestrators (in our example, "1\_1"). 1. Copy the Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator package to the replacement Orchestrator: 1. Connect with WinSCP to the IPv4 address of the "MGMT" port on the replacement Orchestrator. **Important Note** - Refer to [sk42178](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk42178) to make sure this SCP connection works. 2. Go to some path. For example: 3. Upload the Jumbo Hotfix Accumulator package from your computer. 2. Connect with an SSH client to the IPv4 address of the "MGMT" port. 3. Log in to Gaia Clish. 4. Obtain the lock over the Gaia configuration database: 5. Import the CPUSE package from the hard disk: Note: When the import completes, this package is deleted from the original location. `installer import local /` 6. Show the imported packages: `show installer packages imported` 7. Verify the package - see whether this package can be installed without conflicts: `installer verify`_\[press Space key\]\[press Tab key\]_ `installer verify ` 8. Install the package: `installer install ` 9. Wait for the Orchestrator to reboot. 14. On the replacement Orchestrator, import the Gaia backup file from the failed Orchestrator. You can import this Gaia backup in Gaia Portal (recommended) or in Gaia Clish. - To import this Gaia backup in Gaia Portal: 1. With a web browser, connect to the replacement Orchestrator: `https://` Log in with the username "`admin`" and the new password you configured in the First Time Configuration Wizard. 2. Go to **Maintenance** > **System Backup**. 3. Click **Import** > select the Gaia backup file on your computer. 4. In Gaia Portal, click the imported Gaia backup file. 5. Click **Restore**. 6. Wait for the Orchestrator to reboot. - To import this Gaia backup in Gaia Clish: 1. Copy the Gaia backup file from your computer to the replacement Orchestrator: 1. Connect with WinSCP to the replacement Orchestrator. **Important Note** - Refer to [sk42178](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk42178) to make sure this SCP connection works. 2. Go to this path: `/var/log/CPbackup/backups/` 3. Upload the Gaia backup file from your computer. 2. Connect to the command line on the replacement Orchestrator. 3. Log in to Gaia Clish. 4. Restore the local Gaia backup: `set backup restore ` 5. Wait for the Orchestrator to reboot. 15. If previously you configured the authentication between Orchestrators, you must configure it again (between all working Orchestrators) to trust the replacement Orchestrator. See the [R82 Scalable Platforms Administration Guide](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R82/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R82_ScalablePlatforms_AdminGuide/Default.htm#cshid=ID002) > Chapter "**Working with Quantum Maestro**" > Section "**Authentication between Maestro Orchestrators**". You can configure the authentication in Gaia Portal (recommended) or in CLI (Gaia Clish, or Expert mode). 16. On all Orchestrators, make sure the traffic can pass between Orchestrators: - In a Single Site deployment: On a working Orchestrator (in our example, "1\_1"), send several pings to the replacement Orchestrator (in our example, "1\_2"): - In a Dual Site deployment: On the replacement Orchestrator (in our example, "1\_2"), send several pings to **each** working Orchestrator:

ping -c 5 1_1

ping -c 5 2_1

ping -c 5 2_2

17. Make sure the Security Group Members can pass traffic to each other: 1. Connect to the command line on the Security Group. 2. Log in to the Expert mode. 3. Identify the Security Group Member that runs as SMO: 4. If the SMO task runs on another Security Group Member than the Security Group Member to which you are connected, then go to the context of that SMO Security Group Member: `member _` Example: `member 1_2` 5. Examine the cluster state of the Security Group Members. The output must show the state of **each** Security Group Member as "`ACTIVE`". 6. Send several pings between Security Group Members: 1. Connect to one of the Security Group Members (in our example, we connect to the first one - "1\_1"): 2. On this Security Group Member, send several pings to any other Security Group Member (in our example, we send several pings to the second one - "1\_2" / "2\_2"): - In a Single Site deployment: - In a Dual Site deployment:

ping -c 5 1_2

ping -c 5 2_2

18. On the replacement Orchestrator, connect the **Uplink** cables to the ports with the same numbers as they were connected on the failed Orchestrator. 19. On each Security Group, make sure all the required links have the status "`UP`": 1. Connect to the command line on the Security Group. 2. Log in. 3. If your default shell is the Expert mode, then go to Gaia gClish: 4. Examine the state of links: `show cluster info interfaces` ### Procedure for Orchestrators that run the R82 version - when the failed Orchestrator is not accessible Show / Hide this section 1. On a working Orchestrator, export the configuration files for the failed Orchestrator: 1. Connect to the command line on the working Orchestrator - the peer Orchestrator on the same Site. 2. Log in to Gaia Clish. 3. Export the configuration files for the failed Orchestrator: `set maestro export remote orchestrator id configuration archive-name path ` Example: `set maestro export remote orchestrator id 1_2 configuration archive-name Export_Of_Config_for_Failed_Orch_1_2 path /var/log/` The output file is: `/var/log/Export_Of_Config_for_Failed_Orch_1_2.tgz` 2. Copy the archive with the exported configuration files from the working Orchestrator: 1. Connect with WinSCP to this working Orchestrator. **Important Note** - Refer to [sk42178](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk42178) to make sure this SCP connection works. 2. Go to the path you used during the export: `` In our example, go to: `/var/log/` 3. Download the archive file to your computer. In our example, download this file: `Export_Of_Config_for_Failed_Orch_1_2.tgz` 3. On the failed Orchestrator, stop the Orchestrator service: 1. Connect to the command line on the failed Orchestrator. 2. Log in to the Expert mode. 3. Stop the service: 4. assets.title: ProductQuantum Security Gateways: LOM and IPMI
assets.raw:
ProductQuantum Security Gateways

VersionR80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20

OSGaia

Platform23000, 26000, 28000, 5000, 6000, 7000, 9000

Last Modified2024-08-19

#### For internal users only

## Solution

This article shows how to troubleshoot these issues:

-   How to check LOM status and start or stop the IPMI service
-   How to check the LOM version or Type
-   How to configure LOM IP and LAN settings
-   How to reset LOM Admin Password
-   How to reset the LOM to factory defaults
-   How to troubleshoot various LOM commands
-   The `show lom` command returns one of these errors:
    
    `> show lom   CLINFR0329 Invalid command:'show lom'.`  
    `> show lom`  
    `LomErr 03 Get LOM information failed`  
    `> show lom   LOM is not installed`
    

-   When using WebUI to login to LOM you get "Session Expired" error.
-   Restoring the appliance to factory default does not resolve the issue.

**Background  
**Before we jump to solutions lets review how the LOM and IPMI interoperate.Â Â 

Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) is a open standard for configuring monitoring hardware. Â â€˜ipmitoolâ€™ is the primary command line utility to configure ipmi hardware such as Lights Out Management (LOM). Â Check Point has some GAIA scripts which run from CLISH or Expert mode to interface with ipmitool. Â Any of the methods can be used to configure the LOM hardware.

The Gateway appliance runs a â€˜ipmiâ€™ service under GAIA and the LOM card runs a â€˜ipmiâ€™ service on itâ€™s operating system. Â The LOM card plugs into a connector on the motherboard and the two 'ipmi' services communicate with each other over the â€˜LPCâ€™ bus. Â Starting the Gaia â€˜ipmiâ€™ service with command Â â€œservice ipmi startâ€ is only required if the GAIA or clish commands are needed to configure the LOM or if the LOM is not responding with LOM info

The IPMI service is not required to be running on the Gateway appliance to allow your browser to connect to the LOM IP (https://<lom\_IP>. If the Gateway device is not allowing you to start IPMI service, then you will not be able to login or configure LOM via the ipmitool utility or the clish>show lom or >set lom commands.Â 

The instructions below explain how to use the GAIA scripts to start service or try to manually start the 3 IPMI drivers. Or if nothing works, RMA the LOM.

NOTE:Â  Most Check Point Gateway Appliances use LOM's based on Java.Â  Smart1 Management appliances typically use LOM's based on HTML-5. Â The information in this SK is specifically for the LOM Java-based cards. Â (it may be slightly different for HTML-5 based LOM.)  

### How to check LOM status and start or stop the IPMI service

Verify IPMI drivers are running. Use Start or Stop flags to change status.  
`# service ipmi status   # service ipmi start   # service ipmi stop`

### How to check the LOM version or Type

If you see your LOM version is lower than the version in [sk88064](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk88064 "LOM Card Firmware version map") please update the LOM firmware before troubleshooting other errors.

#### Using Expert Mode CLI:

`[Expert@gw]# lominfo`  
`Firmware Revision : 0.25`  
`IP Address : 172.25.48.137`

OrÂ 

`[Expert@gw]# ipmitool mc info`  
`Device ID Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  : 32`  
`Device Revision Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  : 1`  
`Firmware Revision Â  Â  Â  Â  : 0.25`  
`IPMI Version Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â : 2.0`  
`Manufacturer ID Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  : 0`  
`Manufacturer Name Â  Â  Â  Â  : Unknown`  
`Product ID Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â : 43707 (0xaabb)`  
`Product Name Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â : Unknown (0xAABB)`  
`Device Available Â  Â  Â  Â  Â : yes`  
`Provides Device SDRs Â  Â  Â : no`  
`Additional Device Support :`  
Â  Â  `Sensor Device`  
Â  Â  `SDR Repository Device`  
Â  Â  `SEL Device`  
Â  Â  `FRU Inventory Device`  
Â  Â  `IPMB Event Receiver`  
Â  Â  `IPMB Event Generator`  
Â  Â  `Chassis Device`  
`Aux Firmware Rev Info Â  Â  :`  
Â  Â  `0x47`  
Â  Â  `0x5b`  
Â  Â  `0xab`  
Â  Â  `0x00`

#### Using Clish:

`> show asset lom-info`  
`LOM Status: Installed`  
`LOM Firmware Revision: 0.25`

`> show lom`  
`ip-address - Show LOM IP address`  
`sel Â  Â  Â  Â - Show LOM System event logs`  
`sensors Â  Â - Show LOM Sensors information`  
`type Â  Â  Â  - Show LOM card type, "JAVA based LOM" or "HTML5 based LOM"`  
`version Â  Â - Show LOM firmware version`

`> show lom`  
`Firmware Revision : 5.18`  
`IP Address : 172.25.48.137`

`> show lom type`  
`Card: AST2300`  
`JAVA based LOM`

### How to configure LOM IP and LAN settings

#### Using Expert Mode CLI:

Check current LAN settings.  
`# ipmitool lan print 8`  
Configure a new IP, netmask and gateway on LOM.  
`# lomipset 172.25.48.137 255.255.255.0 172.25.48.254`

#### Using Clish:

Check current LAN settings `show lom ip-address`  
Configure a new IP, netmask and gateway on LOM.  
`> set lom ip-address 172.25.48.137 subnet-mask 255.255.255.0 gateway 172.25.48.254   Setting LOM interface network connection, please wait...`

  

### How to reset LOM Admin Password

If you see a login prompt but do not know the password then the "LOM Admin Guide - Logging In to the LOM WebUI" says the default LOM userid/password is admin/admin. If you fail to login with Admin/Admin that means someone has previously logged in and was forced to change the password. Â If you donâ€™t know the password, proceed with reset steps here. Â 

You need to first reset the "admin" user password using the ipmitool command. Â Please follow the requirements in step 7 of the LOM Admin Guide otherwise you will get this error "Set User Password command failed (user 2): Invalid data field in request" when you set the new password  
â€¢ Â The password requirements:

-   Â  Â 8 - 16 characters long
-   Â  Â Does not include the username
-   Â  Â No spaces
-   Â  Â Must contain characters from three of these four categories:

-   Â  Â English uppercase characters (A through Z)
-   Â  Â English lowercase characters (a through z)
-   Â  Â Digits 0 through 9
-   Â  Â Non-alphanumeric characters: ~ ! @ # $ % ^ & \*

Steps:1.  List all LOM users
2.  Reset password for LOM "admin" user.Â 

-   `# ipmitool user list 2`
-   `# ipmitool user set password <ID_for_admin>`

Example:  
`# ipmitool user list 2`  
`ID Â Name Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Enabled Callin Â Link Auth Â IPMI Msg Â  Channel Priv Limit`  
`1 Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â true Â  Â false Â  false Â  Â  Â true Â  Â  Â  ADMINISTRATOR`  
`2 Â  admin Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â true Â  Â false Â  false Â  Â  Â true Â  Â  Â  ADMINISTRATOR`

Reset password for LOM user â€œadminâ€ which is ID 2:  
`# ipmitool user set password 2`  
`Password for user 2:`  
`Password for user 2:`

Now you can proceed to open the LOM WebUI and login as admin with the new password you just set.

### How to reset the LOM to factory defaults

The LOM will lose all configuration and the default userid and password will be "admin" and "admin".Â  Â See sk127573.  
`# ipmitool raw 0x2e 0x02`

  

### How to troubleshoot various LOM commands

To troubleshoot the "show lom" errors, Session Expired or if restoring factory default does not resolve the issue, follow these steps.Â   
**Note:** Â These commands are frequently a solution when a previous session is hung from connecting to LOM via WEB and see "Session Expired" error, you can try one of the following for reset:

#### Instructions

1.  Identify the current state of the LOM:  
    `# ipmitool lan print <Number_of_Channel>`
2.  To check the relevant Channel's number, refer to [sk92986: How to check and set an IP address of a LOM card on a Check Point appliance](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk92986).Â 

-   example: `# ipmitool lan print 8`

4.  Interact with IPMI service from the GAIA OS level. Try to restart the service:  
    -   `# service ipmi status`
    -   `# service ipmi stop`
    -   `# service ipmi start`
5.  Are 'ipmi' services running?Â   
    `ps -aux |grep ipmi`  
    If not, then try running the 3 modprobe commands and see if one of those creates an error.  
    `# modprobe ipmi_msghandler   # modprobe ipmi_devintf   # modprobe ipmi_si`
6.  If ipmi services are running and you can not get a reply from the ipmi commands that may indicate your LOM is hung.Â  The only way to restart the hung LOM is to power cycle the Appliance, wait 5 minutes, then turn appliance on.
7.  If ipmi services are running and you now see repsonses from the ipmi commands you can try to reboot the LOM from the cli.

-   `> show lom Firmware Revision : 5.18 IP Address : 172.25.48.137`  
    -   `# ipmitool mc reset cold`

9.  If ipmi services will not start we can try several options:

-   Follow sk167074 and run `# echo 'options ipmi_si type="kcs" ports="0xca8" regspacings="4"' >> /etc/modprobe.conf # service ipmi start`
-   Disconnect electricity from the machine in order to power down the LOM.
    
    **Note:** It is possible that you may be able to interact with LOM via WEB, but still be unable to see the LOM's IP address with the following command:
    
    -   `> show lom`
    
    `CLINFR0329 Invalid command:'show lom'.`
    
      
    If this occurs, run these commands to manually load the necessary drivers, and try again:  
    
    -   `# modprobe ipmi_msghandler`
    -   `# modprobe ipmi_devintf`
    -   `# modprobe ipmi_si`
    
      
    If the driver fails to load, the reason may be a frozen or faulty LOM. These errors appear in _/var/log/messages_:
    -   `Could not open device at /dev.ipmi or /dev/ipmi/0: No such file or directory`Â 
-   If ipmi services are running and you do see a login banner on the LOM WebUI but you can not login. You have a couple options:
    -   Use the "ipmitool user" command to reset password by finding the ID for the admin user, resetting the password.Â  Prompts will ask for new password 2 times. See "How To" section above.
    -   Follow sk127573 and reset LOM to factory defaults. The LOM will lose all configuration and the default userid and password will be "admin" and "admin".  
        `# ipmitool raw 0x2e 0x02`
-   If the steps above do not resolve the issue, you last resort is to request an RMA for the LOM Board. [Contact Check Point Support](https://www.checkpoint.com/support-services/contact-support/) to open an RMA request. For more information about Check Point's RMA policy click [here](https://www.checkpoint.com/support-services/rma-return-process/).
    
    ### References
    
-   GitHub - ipmitool/ipmitool: An open-source tool for controlling IPMI-enabled systems
-   [sk92986](https://support.checkpoint.com/results/sk/sk92986) -How to check and set an IP address of a LOM card on a Check Point appliance

This solution has been verified for the specific scenario, described by the combination of Product, Version and Symptoms. It may not work in other scenarios.

VersionR80.20SP (EOS), R80.30SP (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82

Last Modified2025-04-20

#### For internal users only

## Symptoms

-   Pull registry fails during a configuration pull on a Scalable Platform environment.
    
    **Note**: You recently updated the licenses, or this is a new implementation.
    
-   There is a pull\_config pnote on some Security Group Members.
    
-   The `$FWDIR/log/blade_config` file contains a "`Pull registry failed`" log.
    

## Cause

The "registry pull" can fail because of these three files:

-   `/var/log/merge_license_file.log`
-   `$CPDIR/conf/cp.license`
-   `$CPDIR/conf/cp.license.smo`

These three files are responsible for the license's integrity across the Scalable Platform environment.

## ATRG: CloudGuard Network for Azure - High Availability (HA) ProductCloudGuard Network for Azure VersionR80.40 (EOS), R81 (EOS), R81.10, R81.20, R82 OSGaia PlatformAzure Last Modified2024-10-27 ## Solution **Table of Contents** - Introduction - Important Information - FAQ - Errors and Troubleshooting - General - Tester - Failover - Traffic - Contact Check Point Support ** Note:** To stay up-to-date refer to [CloudGuard for Azure latest updates](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk132192) Click Here to Collapse the Entire Sections ## Introduction The CloudGuard Network cloud security solution delivers advanced Threat Protection to private or public cloud infrastructures. It controls and manages the security in both the physical and virtual environments with one unified management solution. A cluster is a group of Virtual Machines that work together in a High Availability Mode. One Cluster Member is the Active, and the second Cluster Member is the Standby. The cluster fails over from the Active Cluster Member to the Standby Cluster Member when necessary. - Cluster Members communicate with each other using unicast IP addresses. - For inbound, outbound, and East-West traffic, Cluster Members rely on Azure Load Balancers to represent their external and internal Virtual IP addresses. Load Balancers only forward traffic to the Active Cluster Member. - For VPN traffic, Cluster Members use API calls to Azure to communicate the failover from the Active Cluster Member. The Standby Cluster Member then promotes itself to Active. During cluster failover, the Standby Cluster Member associates the Active Cluster Member's private and public cluster IP addresses with its external interface. **To get additional information about the solution, refer to:** - [CloudGuard Network for Azure HA Admin Guide](https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/IaaS/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_CloudGuard_Network_for_Azure_HA_Cluster/Default.htm) - [CloudGuard Network for Public Cloud - Frequently Asked Questions](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk174006) - [CloudGuard Network for Public Cloud - Important Resources](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk173705) - [CloudGuard Network for Public Cloud - Performance Data Sheets](https://supportcenter.checkpoint.com/supportcenter/portal?eventSubmit_doGoviewsolutiondetails=&solutionid=sk171052) ## Important Information
